Alt det ovennevnte betyr ikke at MR aldri er nyttig. Det finnes klare situasjoner hvor rask utredning er helt avgjørende.

Pasient 45 år, akutte korsryggsmerter etter løft, ingen utstråling, positiv Kemp test.

Primærkode: L84 Ryggsyndromer uten utstråling
Begrunnelse: Akutt mekanisk korsryggsmerte uten nevrologiske funn. Kemp-positiv tyder på fasettleddsaffeksjon.
Sekundær: Ingen nødvendig.

Beskriv Hvem rammes av hallux valgus? for Hallux Valgus (Knokkeltopp).

Hvem rammes av hallux valgus?

 

 Hallux valgus er den vanligste feilstillingen i forfoten og rammer omtrent 19% av befolkningen. Prevalensen Øker med alderen til ca. 36% hos de over 65 Ør.

 Kvinner rammes 2-3 ganger oftere enn menn, trolig på grunn av en kombinasjon av genetiske faktorer og bruk av trange sko og høye heler.

 
 
 19%
 av befolkningen rammes
 

 
 36%
 prevalens over 65 Ør
 

 
 2-3x
 oftere hos kvinner
 

 
 63-90%
 arvelighetskomponent

Forklar hvorfor øvelser hjelper ved isjias for 5 Øvelser som Lindrer Isjiassmerter.

Hvorfor øvelser Hjelper ved Isjias

 Ved isjias er nerven irritert - enten av en prolaps, tranghet eller betennelse. Riktige øvelser kan
 Redusere trykk på nerven ved å endre belastningsforholdet

 Bedre nervens glideevne gjennom forsiktig mobilisering

 Styrke støttemuskulaturen for langsiktig forebygging

 Redusere inflammasjon ved å fremme blodsirkulasjon

 Det Viktigste Prinsippet: Sentralisering vs. Periferialisering

 Sentralisering: Smerten trekker seg fra benet og tilbake mot ryggen. Dette er et godt tegn! 

 Periferialisering: Smerten sprer seg lengre ned i benet. Stopp og prøv en annen tilnærming! 

 Hvis en øvelse gir sentralisering, fortsett med den. Hvis den gir periferialisering, stopp.
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe Prevention for Hip Sports Injuries.

Prevention

 

 
 Adequate warm-up: Minimum 15-20 minutes before intense activity

 Progressive load increase: Don't increase volume/intensity more than
 10% per week

 Strength training: Focus on hip muscles, especially adductors and
 gluteus

 Mobility: Maintain good hip mobility in all planes

 Recovery: Adequate rest between intense sessions

 Nutrition: Adequate energy intake and protein for tissue repair

 

 
 Copenhagen Adductor Protocol

 A specific exercise that has been shown to reduce groin injuries by up to 41% in
 football. The exercise is done in a side-lying position where a partner holds the top
 leg, and the athlete lifts the body up with the bottom leg. Start with 2x5 repetitions
 and gradually increase to 3x15.

Vanligvis ikke. En grundig klinisk undersøkelse er ofte tilstrekkelig for å stille diagnose og starte behandling. Billeddiagnostikk vurderes kun ved mistanke om alvorlig skade eller hvis plagene ikke ...
You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What is the prognosis for BPPV (Crystal Disease)?

Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).
You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain exercises for specific conditions for Hip Exercises and Pelvic Training.

Exercises for specific conditions

 Different hip conditions require different approaches. Here are recommended adaptations based on your condition.

 Hip osteoarthritis

 Most common 

 Exercise is first-line treatment for hip osteoarthritis - pain relief is comparable to NSAIDs (network MA, 2023). Norway's AktivA program is based on this evidence.

 Daily mobility - knee-to-chest and hip rotations

 Strength 2-3x/week - glute bridge and clamshell with light load

 Aquatic exercise is excellent - offloads the joint by 50-75%

 Cycling over running - lower load on the cartilage

 Avoid deep squats below 90 degrees if painful

 GTPS / Gluteal tendinopathy

 For GTPS , progressive loading is the core of treatment - 7 out of 10 see significant improvement after 8 weeks of exercises (JOSPT, 2015).

 Start isometric: 5 reps x 45-60 sec hold, 40-70% of max force, 2-3x/day

 Progression: Isometric → isotonic → functional strength

 AVOID stretching across the trochanter - adductor stretches, IT band stretching and crossing the legs compress the tendon

 AVOID lying on the affected side

 All exercises in slight abduction (avoid the hip falling inward)

 SI joint problems

 For SI joint problems , stability is more important than mobility. Pelvic stabilization is the keyword.

 Symmetric exercises - glute bridge, pelvic tilt, dead bug

 Pelvic floor and deep stabilizers first

 Avoid heavy unilateral loading during the acute phase

 A pelvic belt can help with significant instability

 Gradual transition to single-leg exercises as pain subsides

 Piriformis syndrome

 For piriformis syndrome , gentle stretching is combined with gluteal strengthening.

 Gentle piriformis stretch - figure-4, not aggressive

 Gluteal strengthening - clamshell and glute bridge

 Avoid prolonged sitting - stand up every 30-45 minutes

 Gentle foam rolling on the piriformis can provide relief

 Neural flossing for sciatic component

Describe symptoms for Chronic Ankle Instability.

Symptoms

 The most common symptoms of chronic ankle instability
 "Giving way": The ankle suddenly gives out, especially on uneven surfaces

 Feeling of instability: You don't trust the ankle and avoid certain activities

 Repeated sprains: New rolling incidents even with little provocation

 Persistent pain: Often diffuse pain on the outside of the ankle (see also stress fracture in the foot as a differential diagnosis)

 Swelling: Episodic swelling after activity

 Stiffness: Especially in the morning or after rest

 When should you seek help?

 The ankle gives way more than 2 times per month

 You avoid activities you previously enjoyed

 Pain or swelling that doesn't resolve

 Locking or clicking in the ankle joint

 Numbness or weakness in the foot

Beskriv Bør jeg unngå all aktivitet? i kontekst av Kalkskulder: Alt du trenger å vite.

Bør jeg unngå all aktivitet?

 Nei. I akutt fase bør du unngå bevegelser som provoserer smerte, men fullstendig hvile anbefales ikke. Tilpasset aktivitet innenfor smertefrie grenser hjelper med å opprettholde bevegelighet.

Describe What Is Lumbago? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Lumbago?

 

 
 Lumbago is what most people have when their back "locks up". The medical term is acute lumbago or non-specific low back pain. The pain comes suddenly, often after an awkward movement, lift or twist - but can also occur seemingly without reason.
 

 
 Characteristics of lumbago:

 
 Localized pain in the lower back

 Pain may radiate diffusely to the buttocks or thighs, but never below the knee

 Stiff back with limited mobility

 Worst in the first few days, then gradual improvement

 No tingling, numbness or muscle weakness

 
 

 
 With lumbago, no specific structural cause is found. MRI or X-ray often shows "normal" age-related changes that don't explain the pain. This is actually good news: it means your body isn't damaged.
 

 
 Most people improve significantly within 6 weeks. Pain scores typically fall from around 56/100 to 26/100 during this period (Pengel et al., BMJ 2003). However, we must be honest: 33-73% experience recurrence within one year, and some develop chronic symptoms.

Hvilke faresignaler bør man være oppmerksom på ved Fibromyalgi med Brystsmerter?

Søk lege/legevakt UMIDDELBART ved
 Trykkende, klemmende brystsmerter

 Brystsmerter ved anstrengelse som lindres av hvile

 Disse symptomene kan skyldes hjerteinfarkt, lungeemboli eller andre livstruende tilstander.

What warning signs should be monitored for Acute Torticollis?

Seek medical attention or emergency room if you have
 Fever combined with sore throat and headache

 Increased drooling or difficulty swallowing

 Weakness or numbness in arms or legs

 Walking problems or balance issues

 Vision disturbances or double vision

Hva forårsaker Scheuermanns sykdom?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Den eksakte Årsaken er ikke fullstendig forstått, men flere faktorer ser ut til å spille inn:

 
 Hovedfaktorer

 
 Genetikk (vanligst): Med 74% arvelighet er genetiske faktorer den dominerende risikofaktoren. Tilstanden går ofte i familier.

 Mekanisk belastning: Teori om traction apophysitis - drag på vekstplatene under rask vekst.

 Vaskulare faktorer: Mulig nedsatt blodtilførsel til deler av virvlene under vekst.

 Biomekaniske forhold: Stram muskulatur i baksiden av lærene (hamstrings) kan forsterke belastningen.

 
 

 
 Viktig å vite

 Scheuermanns sykdom skyldes IKKE dårlig holdning - det er en strukturell tilstand, ikke et resultat av vaner.

Patient asks: "When does my child need a brace?"

Bracing is considered when the Cobb angle is between 25 and 40 degrees in children and adolescents who are still growing (Risser 0–2). The BrAIST study showed a 72% success rate with bracing compared to 48% with observation alone (Weinstein et al. 2013, NEJM). The assessment is made by an orthopedic specialist.

Describe symptoms and diagnosis for De Quervain's Tenosynovitis: Complete Guide.

Symptoms and diagnosis

 Pain on the thumb side of wrist, at "anatomical snuffbox"

 Worsens with gripping - especially "L-grip" and thumb movements

 Swelling over tendon sheath

 Crepitus - grinding sensation with thumb movement

 Pain that radiates up into forearm or down into thumb (can be confused with thumb arthritis )

 Finkelstein's test

 The classic diagnostic test: Place thumb in palm, make a fist around it, and bend wrist toward little
 finger side. If this reproduces the pain, the test is positive.

Describe Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis) for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)

 

 Frozen shoulder is a condition where the joint capsule around the shoulder becomes thick, inflamed and tight. This leads to gradually increasing stiffness and pain. The condition goes through three characteristic phases:

 
 Freezing Phase (2-9 months)

 Gradually increasing pain and stiffness. Night pain can be intense.

 

 
 Frozen Phase (4-12 months)

 Pain decreases somewhat, but stiffness is at its worst. Daily activities become difficult.

 

 
 Thawing Phase (6-24 months)

 Movement gradually returns. Full recovery can take 1-3 years.

 

 
 Who gets frozen shoulder?

 Diabetes significantly increases the risk - diabetics have 5 times higher probability of developing frozen shoulder. Other risk factors are thyroid disorders and prolonged inactivity after injury or surgery.

 

 
 Prognosis: Although it takes time, 80% of patients regain good shoulder function with proper follow-up. Early treatment can reduce severity and duration.

Beskriv Hvordan Tekstnakke Påvirker Kjeven for Tekstnakke og Kjevesmerter: Hvordan Mobilbruk Påvirker Kjeven.

Hvordan Tekstnakke Påvirker Kjeven

 

 Sammenhengen mellom fremoverlent hode og kjeveplager er godt dokumentert:

 
 1. Biomekanisk Endring

 Når hodet skyves fremover:

 
 Underkjeven trekkes bakover og ned av tyngdekraften

 Kjevemusklene må jobbe for å holde munnen lukket

 Kjeveleddet belastes asymmetrisk

 Bakre del av leddet komprimeres

 
 

 
 2. Muskulær Kompensasjon

 
 Masseter og temporalis aktiveres unødvendig

 Konstant lav-nivå spenning fører til utmatting

 Økt risiko for triggerpunkter

 Spenningshodepine i tinninger

 
 

 
 3. Nerveforbindelser

 
 Trigeminocervical-komplekset kobler nakke og kjeve

 Stram nakkemuskulatur kan gi henvist smerte til kjeven

 Suboccipital spenning påvirker kjevemuskulaturen reflektorisk

 
 

 
 Forskning Bekrefter Sammenhengen

 Studier viser at 70-90% av TMD-pasienter har samtidige nakkeproblemer, og at behandling av nakken ofte forbedrer kjevesymptomene - selv uten direkte kjevebehandling.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for De Quervains tenosynovitt: Komplett guide.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Repetitiv tommelbruk (vanligst)

 Gjentatte grep- og tommelbevegelser over tid - mobiltasting, gaming, handarbeid. Lignende mekanismer som ved musearm .

 Nyfodte/små barn

 Repetitiv løfting med "L-grep" belaster senene betydelig. Vanlig hos nybakte foreldre.

 Hormonelle faktorer

 Graviditet og amming øker risikoen. Hormonelle endringer påvirker senevevet.

 Direkte traume

 Slag eller fall mot tommelsiden av handleddet kan utlose tilstanden.

Beskriv Pauser og bevegelse for Hjemmekontor Ergonomi: Slik Unngår Du Vondt i Rygg og Nakke.

Pauser og bevegelse

 

 Selv den perfekte ergonomiske oppsetningen hjelper lite hvis du sitter stille i timevis. Kroppen er laget for bevegelse.

 
 30-minutters regelen

 
 Reis deg og beveg deg minst hvert 30. minutt

 Sett en timer eller bruk en app som påminner deg

 Bare det å reise seg og sette seg ned igjen har effekt

 
 

 
 Mikropauser

 
 Strekk nakken forsiktig fra side til side

 Rull skuldrene bakover noen ganger

 Strekk hendene og fingrene

 Gjør noen knebøy eller tåhev

 
 

 
 20-20-20 regelen for øynene

 Hvert 20. minutt: Se på noe 20 fot (ca. 6 meter) unna i 20 sekunder. Dette avlaster øyemuskulaturen og forebygger digital øyebelastning.

 

 
 Innbygg bevegelse i arbeidsdagen

 
 Ta telefonsamtaler stående eller gående

 Gå til et annet rom for å drikke vann

 Gjør 5 minutter med tøyeøvelser mellom møter

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 60-year-old male with known spinal stenosis. Has had bilateral claudication for years. Today reports reduced ability to control bowel movements over past few days. No change in back pain.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible cauda equina syndrome — sphincter involvement in known stenosis.

Clinical reasoning:
- Patient has KNOWN stenosis with longstanding claudication — this is his "baseline"
- NEW sphincter dysfunction (fecal incontinence) = new neurological deterioration
- Fecal incontinence is a LATE sign of CES (more alarming than urinary retention alone)
- That back pain is UNCHANGED is irrelevant — CES can progress without pain worsening
- Known stenosis = anatomical substrate for acute compression

Key lesson: New sphincter dysfunction in patient with known stenosis = CES regardless of pain level.

ACTION: Call emergency services. Urgent MRI. Neurosurgical consultation for decompression.
Du er en erfaren kiropraktor-assistent. Hjelp med klinisk dokumentasjon, SOAP-notater og pasientkommunikasjon. Bruk norsk fagterminologi og følg ICPC-2 kodeverket.
Skriv SOAP for 2. konsultasjon etter akutt whiplash (7 dager etter ulykke).

S: 2. konsultasjon, 7 dager post-MVA. Pas. rapporterer smerte uendret (VAS 7/10). Hodepine persisterer (daglig, occipitalt). Ny symptom: Konsentrasjonsvansker. Søvn dårlig — våkner av smerter 3x/natt. Har vært sykmeldt. Bruker paracetamol 1g x4.

O: Cervikal ROM: Uendret fra baseline, fortsatt globalt redusert ~50%. Myofascial: SCM og trapezius like ømme. C2-C3 restriksjon vedvarer. Ny test: Cervikal fleksjon rotasjon test positiv V (indikerer C1-C2 dysfunksjon).

A: WAD grad II, 1 uke post-traume — stabil (ikke forverret, ikke bedret).
   Forventningsavklaring: Noen WAD-pasienter har forsinket bedring.
   Konsentrasjonsvanker monitoreres (mulig mild hjernerysting).

P: 1) Fortsatt forsiktig mobilisering (ikke manipulasjon i akuttfase)
   2) Myofascial frigjøring SCM, scaleni, suboccipitalt
   3) Hjemmeøvelser: Isometrisk nakkestyrking, gentle ROM
   4) SCAT6-screening ved neste konsultasjon (konsentrasjonsvansker)
   5) Neste time om 3-4 dager
   6) Forsikringsdokumentasjon oppdatert

Describe differential diagnoses for Trigger Points in the Neck.

Differential Diagnoses

 It's important to distinguish trigger points from other conditions that can cause similar symptoms
 Cervical Radiculopathy (Nerve Root Involvement)

 Follows dermatomal patterns (specific skin areas), often with tingling/numbness and weakness. Trigger
 points follow muscle-specific radiation patterns.

 Fibromyalgia

 Widespread pain for more than 3 months, with tenderness in many areas of the body, often with fatigue
 and sleep problems.

 Cervical Facet Joint Arthrosis

 Pain from the joints between vertebrae, often with morning stiffness that improves throughout the day.

Pasient spør: "Hva er cervikogen svimmelhet?"

Cervikogen svimmelhet skyldes nakkeproblemer og rammer ca 40% av pasienter med nakkesmerter. Nakken inneholder mange stillingsfølere, og når disse sender feil signaler oppstar konflikt mellom nakken og balanseorganet i Øret.

Beskriv Første konsultasjon (ca. 45 minutter) i kontekst av Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Første konsultasjon (ca. 45 minutter)

 Ved første konsultasjon får du en grundig undersøkelse med:

 
 Sykehistorie og smertekartlegging

 Fysisk undersøkelse av kne, hofte og ankel

 Vurdering av bevegelsesmønstre og muskelstyrke

 Eventuell henvisning til bildediagnostikk hvis nødvendig

 
 

 Behandlingen tilpasses din tilstand og kan inkludere: leddmobilisering, bløtvevsbehandling, tøyning, dry needling, trykkbølgebehandling (for seneplager), og ikke minst å et individuelt Øvelsesprogram.

 
 HjemmeØvelser å nåkkelen til bedring

 Øvelser du gjør selv mellom behandlingene er avgjørende for resultatet. Typiske fokusområder:

 
 Quadriceps-styrke: Knebøy, utfall, step-ups

 Hoftemuskulatur: Gluteus-Øvelser, sideliggende beinhev, bridging

 Balanse og propriosepsjon: Ettbeins-stående, balansebrett

 Tøyning: Quadriceps, hamstrings, leggmuskulatur

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 42-year-old female, progressive bilateral hand weakness over 6 weeks, difficulty with buttons, urinary urgency, unsteady gait, Lhermitte sign positive.

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible cervical myelopathy.

Findings:
- Progressive bilateral upper limb weakness
- Fine motor dysfunction (buttons)
- Bladder dysfunction (urgency)
- Gait disturbance
- Positive Lhermitte sign

ACTION: Urgent MRI cervical spine. Refer to neurosurgeon within 24-48 hours. Do NOT perform cervical manipulation. Progressive myelopathy may require surgical decompression.

Kan gi lindring for noen, men evidensen er moderat. Viktig: prefabrikerte innleggssaler fungerer like godt som dyre spesialtilpassede ved plantar fasciopati. Toyning og styrketrening har bedre dokumentasjon.

Hva er prognosen for Spenningshodepine: Alt du trenger å vite?

Prognose - hvordan går det?

 

 Episodisk spenningshodepine har generelt god prognose:

 
 
 75%
 fortsetter kun episodisk
 

 
 ~50%
 remisjon over 3 Ør
 

 
 15-25%
 utvikler kronisk form
 

 

 Risikofaktorer for kronifisering

 
 Medikamentoverforbruk (sterkeste prediktor)

 Samtidig migrene

 Søvnproblemer

 Depresjon og angst

 Stillesittende livsstil

 

 
 Realistiske forventninger

 Tilbakefall er vanlig, spesielt ved kronisk form. Behandling kan gi betydelig lindring og færre hodepinedager, men forebyggende tiltak (trening, stressmestring, gode vaner) må ofte opprettholdes for å holde plagene i sjakk.

Describe 7. Vestibular Neuritis in the context of Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

7. Vestibular Neuritis

 Prevalence: 3-10% in dizziness clinics

 Viral inflammation of the balance nerve causing sudden, intense dizziness lasting several days.

 
 Sudden onset, often after a cold

 Constant, intense vertigo for several days

 No hearing loss (distinguishes from labyrinthitis)

 10-15% develop BPPV afterward

 
 Read more about vestibular neuritis →

Describe diagnosis for Nociplastic Pain: When the Nervous System Becomes Oversensitive.

Diagnosis

 There is no simple test for nociplastic pain. The diagnosis is made clinically based on medical history, symptom patterns, and exclusion of other causes.

 Clinical Assessment

 Thorough medical history focusing on symptom development over time

 Mapping of pain location and spread

 Assessment of sensory phenomena (allodynia, hyperalgesia)

 Screening for anxiety, depression, and sleep disturbances

 Neurological examination to rule out nerve damage

 Standardized Questionnaires

 Central Sensitization Inventory (CSI)

 A validated questionnaire with 25 questions that maps symptoms associated with central sensitization. A score above 40 out of 100 indicates probable central sensitization.

 Pain Catastrophizing Scale

 Maps the degree of catastrophizing about pain, which is associated with central sensitization.

 Imaging

 Important to Know

 MRI and X-rays cannot detect nociplastic pain. Imaging is primarily used to rule out other causes (red flags, nerve compression, etc.). Findings such as disc degeneration and osteoarthritis are common in pain-free individuals as well and do not explain nociplastic pain.

Explain Neck Degeneration to a patient.

You just received your MRI results, and words like "degenerative changes," "spondylosis," and
 "degeneration" fill the report. It sounds serious - as if your neck is about to fall apart.

 But here's the good news: Degenerative changes are a normal part of aging, much like gray hair or
 wrinkles. Most people over 50 have such findings on MRI - and many of them have no pain whatsoever.

 Let's look at what these MRI findings actually mean, why they often don't explain your pain, and what
 you can do to feel better.

Describe causes and risk factors for GTPS.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Compression is the Main Problem

 The gluteal tendons become compressed against the greater trochanter in certain positions and
 movements
 Side-lying - especially on the affected side

 Standing with hip pushed out to the side ("hanging on one hip")

 Crossing legs when sitting

 Walking up stairs or uphill

 Sudden increase in activity - e.g., lots of walking on vacation

 Risk Factors

 Female sex - 4 times higher risk

 Age 40-60 years - hormones and natural aging

 Overweight - increases the load

 Weak hip muscles - lack of stability

 Runners - especially with rapid increase in training volume

 Low back pain - often concurrent problems

 Avoid These Habits

 Lying on the painful side without a pillow between the knees

 Standing with all weight on one leg ("sexy stand")

 Sitting with legs crossed

 Aggressive stretching of the hip

Beskriv to hovedtyper idrettsskader - og hvorfor det betyr noe for forebygging for Idrettsskader.

To hovedtyper idrettsskader - og hvorfor det betyr noe for forebygging

 For å forebygge effektivt må du forstå hva slags skader som finnes. Idrettsskader deles i to hovedkategorier som krever helt forskjellig tilnærming.

 Akutte skader

 Akutte skader har en plutselig start med en kjent hendelse. Du tråkker over, du kjenner et rykk, du faller - noe skjer i et bestemt øyeblikk.

 Forstuing (ligamentskade): Ankelforstuing er klassikeren. Graderes I-III fra mild strekk til komplett ruptur

 Muskelstrekk (strain): Hamstring under sprint, leggmuskel ved avtrykk. Også gradert I-III

 Brudd: Fra fall, høyenergitraume eller direkte slag

 Luksasjon: Skulder ut av ledd ved fall eller kontakt i kampidretter

 Overbelastningsskader

 Overbelastningsskader kommer gradvis uten en kjent enkelthendelse. Kroppen tålte ikke summen av belastning over tid.

 Tendinopati: Degenerative forandringer i sener (ikke lenger kalt "betennelse"). Achilles, patella og rotatorcuff er vanligst

 Stressfraktur: Tretthetsbrudd i bein fra repetitiv belastning. Vanlig i legg, fot og hofte hos løpere 

 Bursitt: Irritasjon av slimposer fra friksjon eller repetitiv belastning

 Apofysitt: Vekstsone-irritasjon hos barn og ungdom (Osgood-Schlatter, Severs sykdom)

 Overbelastningsskader er vanligst i utholdenhetsidretter som løping, langrenn og sykling, mens akutte skader dominerer i kontaktidretter som fotball, håndball og rugby. Les mer om spesifikke idrettsskader etter kroppsdel .

Behandling

 

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En Cochrane-oversikt fra 2007 gjennomgikk 23 studier med over 2300 deltakere. Hovedkonklusjonen var tydelig: Tidlig aktiv mobilisering er klart bedre enn hvile og nakkekrage.

 
 Vi bruker forsiktige teknikker tilpasset skadens fase:

 
 Mobilisering: Myke teknikker for å gjenopprette bevegelse i løste ledd. Ved akutt nakkesleng unngår vi kraftig manipulasjon.

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Behandling av stramme muskler som forsøker å "beskytte" nakken.

Describe treatment options for Headache on Top of the Head.

Treatment

 

 Treatment of headache on top of the head focuses on the underlying causes - especially neck structures and musculature.

 
 For Cervicogenic Headache

 Manual treatment has moderate evidence for short-term effect. A 2022 systematic review with 20 studies and 1439 patients found large effect on pain intensity in the short term compared to placebo.

 Important to note: At 12-month follow-up, manual treatment alone did not show better effect than placebo. Neck exercises, however, showed sustained effect.

 

 
 For Tension Headache

 Evidence for manual treatment is more limited. 2011 guidelines concluded that manipulation cannot be recommended for episodic tension headache, but that low-intensity mobilization may be useful for chronic problems.

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Posture Correction

 Avoid forward head posture during screen work. Make sure the screen is at eye level and take regular breaks.

 

 
 Neck Exercises

 Gentle stretches and strengthening exercises for the neck have documented effect. Especially exercises that strengthen the deep neck flexors can be useful.

 

 
 Stress Management

 For tension headache, relaxation, mindfulness or other stress management techniques can help.

 

 
 Limit Pain Medication

 Avoid daily use of paracetamol or NSAIDs to prevent medication overuse headache.

 

 Treatment Course

How is BPPV (Crystal Disease) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made through medical history and clinical examination. The most important tests are:

 
 Dix-Hallpike Test

 The patient sits on the bench with head turned 45 degrees toward the suspected side, then is quickly laid back until the head hangs 20 degrees below the horizontal plane. With posterior canal BPPV, upbeating, rotational nystagmus is seen after a few seconds delay.

 

 
 Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Osteitis Pubis.

Hva er osteitis pubis?: Symphysis pubis er forankringspunktet for to muskelgrupper som trekker i motsatte retninger: rectus abdominis (magemuskulatur som trekker oppover) og adduktorene (innerlarsmuskulatur som trekker nedover). Når disse musklene blir ubalanserte, oppstår det unormale skjaerkrefter gjennom leddet.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer: Fra vanligst til sjeldnest
Symptomer: De fleste opplever en gradvis debut av symptomene over uker til måneder. Smerten er typisk lokalisert over skambensleddet midt foran i bekkenet, men kan også stråle ut til lysken, innerlaret, nedre del av magen eller perineum.

Diagnostikk: Diagnosen stilles primært gjennom sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. Bildediagnostikk brukes for å bekrefte mistanken eller utelukke andre tilstander.

Behandling: Konservativ behandling er førstevalget og gir gode resultater hos de fleste. En systematisk gjennomgang fant at 97,6% av pasienter i case-serier kom tilbake til idrett med konservativ tilnærming. Kirurgi er sjelden nødvendig.

Røde flagg - når du bør kontakte lege: Disse symptomene kan indikere infeksios osteomyelitt, som krever rask medisinsk behandling.

Prognose: Osteitis pubis har generelt god prognose. Tilstanden er selvbegrensende, noe som betyr at de fleste tilfeller vil bedres over tid - men aktiv behandling og rehabilitering gir raskere og bedre resultater enn passiv hvile.

Describe diagnosis - how is the diagnosis made? for SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Diagnosis - How is the Diagnosis Made?

 Clinical Examination is the Gold Standard

 SI joint problems cannot be seen on X-ray or MRI. The diagnosis is made primarily clinically through pain
 location, provocation tests, and palpation. Individual tests have limited value - therefore a
 cluster of provocation tests is used. Three or more positive tests give 94% sensitivity
 and 78% specificity.

 The Five Most Important Provocation Tests

 Distraction test, compression test, thigh thrust, Gaenslen's test, and sacral thrust are used in
 combination to make the diagnosis.

 Differential Diagnosis

 Condition 
 Characteristics 
 Difference from SI Joint 

 Herniation / Sciatica 
 Radiation below knee, sensory loss, weakness 
 Neurological deficits, positive straight leg raise 

 Hip Osteoarthritis 
 Groin pain, stiffness on rotation 
 Pain in front, not back 

 Ank. Spondylitis 
 Bilateral, morning stiffness >30-60 min 
 Onset before 40, improves with activity 

 Piriformis Syndrome 
 Deep buttock pain 
 Worsens with sitting, positive FAIR test

Patient asks: "Can the wrong sleep position cause back pain?"

Yes, sleep position can contribute to back and neck pain. Stomach sleeping increases lumbar loading and forces the neck into rotation. Research shows that back and side sleeping are generally more gentle on the spine (Cary et al., 2021). That said, sleep position is rarely the sole cause, and changing your position should be part of a broader approach.

Ekte isjias vs. falsk isjias

 

 Dette skillet er avgjørende for riktig behandling.

 Ekte isjias (lumbal radikulopati)

 Ved ekte isjias er det faktisk irritasjon eller kompresjon av nerveroten i ryggraden. De vanligste Årsakene, rangert fra hyppigst til sjeldnest:

 
 1. Diskusprolaps (~90% av tilfellene)

 Gelmassen fra skiven buler ut og trykker på nerven. Omtrent 95% av alle lumbale prolapser skjer på L4-L5 eller L5-S1 niva (StatPearls, 2023).

 
 
 
 

 
 2. Spinal stenose

 Trang ryggmargskanal, vanligere hos eldre. Kan gi bilaterale symptomer og forverres ved gange. Les mer om spinal stenose.

 

 
 3. Foraminal stenose

 Tranghet i nerveutgangen fra virvelsoylene. Ofte aldersbetinget slitasje.

 

 
 4. Spondylolistese

 Glidning av en virvel i forhold til en annen. Særlig vanlig ved L5-S1.

 

 Falsk isjias (pseudoiskias)

 Ved falsk isjias er nerven selv ikke i klem. Smerten refereres fra andre strukturer som etterligner isjiassmerte:

 
 1. Triggerpunkter og muskulære Årsaker (vanligst)

 Omme knuter i glutealmuskulatur, quadratus lumborum eller hamstrings kan gi referert smerte ned i benet.

 

 
 2. SI-leddsdysfunksjon

 Referert smerte fra bekkenbaksiden. Gir ofte smerte til setet og baksiden av læret.

 

 
 3. Facettleddssyndrom

 Referert smerte fra leddene mellom virvlene. Typisk forverret ved ekstensjon og rotasjon.

 

 
 4. Piriformis-syndrom (0,3-6% av tilfeller)

 Piriformis-muskelen i setet komprimerer isjiasnerven. Diagnosen er omdiskutert og anses...

Explain treatment for Frozen Shoulder: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 Treatment is tailored to the phase you are in. The goal is to relieve pain, preserve and regain mobility, and support the natural healing process.

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 Phase 1 (Freezing phase) - Focus on pain relief

 Pain relievers/anti-inflammatories as needed

 Gentle movement within pain tolerance

 Avoid aggressive stretching

 Heat can provide relief

 Phase 2 (Frozen phase) - Focus on mobility

 Gradually increasing mobility exercises

 Mobilization with chiropractor/physiotherapist

 Pendulum exercises and passive stretching

 Strength training within pain-free range

 Phase 3 (Thawing phase) - Focus on function

 Progressive mobility training

 Rotator cuff strength training

 Gradual return to normal activities

 Maintenance exercises

 What can a chiropractor do?

 Mobilization: Gentle treatment to preserve and increase mobility

 Soft tissue treatment: Work on tight muscles around the shoulder

 Exercise guidance: Tailored to phase and tolerance

 Neck/back: Treat compensating tension

 Follow-up: Guide through the different phases

 Injection treatment

 Cortisone injection

 Can provide good pain relief, especially in the freezing phase. The effect is often temporary (weeks to months), but can make it easier to start exercises. Read more about cortisone in the shoulder .

 Hydrodilatation

 Injection of fluid into the joint to "expand" the capsule. May be considered in selected cases. Research shows varying results.

 Surgical treatment

 Only considered in prolonged, treatment-resistant cases
 Arthroscopic capsular release

 Keyhole surgery where the surgeon cuts the tight capsule. Relevant for patients who don't respond to conservative treatment after a long time (typically 6-12 months without improvement).

 Manipulation under anesthesia

 The shoulder is moved through its full range under anesthesia to release adhesions. Used less frequently now due to risk of complications.

Hva forårsaker Nummenhet i fingrene - Nakke eller hand??

HandÅrsaker

 

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom

 Den vanligste Årsaken til nummenhet i fingrene. Medianusnerven blir klemt i karpaltunnelen - en trang passasje i handleddet.

 
 Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom

 
 Fingre påvirket: Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger, og halve ringfinger

 Verre om natten: Mange vakner av nummenhet og må riste på handen

 Lindres ved risting: å riste på handen gir ofte kortvarig lindring

 Ingen nakkesmerte: Symptomene er lokalisert til hand og underarm

 Risikofaktorer: Graviditet, diabetes, hypothyreose, repetitivt arbeid

 Svakhet: Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan tommelmuskulaturen bli svakere

 
 

 Ulnarisnerveaffeksjon (Cubitaltunnelsyndrom)

 Ulnarisnerven kan bli klemt ved albuen (cubitaltunnelen) eller ved handleddet (Guyons kanal).

 
 Kjennetegn på ulnarispåvirkning

 
 Fingre påvirket: Lillefinger og halve ringfinger (ulnare halvdel)

 Albueposisjon: Ofte verre ved bøyning av albuen eller ved å hvile på albuen

 Innsiden av handen: Kan gi svakhet i de små handmusklene

 "Klofingre": Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan fingrene få kloliknende stilling

 
 

 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 Nervene og blodarene til armen kan bli klemt i området mellom nakkebasis og armhulen.

 
 Kjennetegn på TOS

 
 Nummenhet og prikking i hele handen eller flere fingre

 Ofte forverret av å holde armene over hodet

 Kan gi kuldefølelse og fargeforandringer i handen

 Ofte forbundet med dårlig holdning eller ekstra nakkeribben

Describe When adaptation becomes pathology in the context of Thrower's Shoulder and GIRD: When Throwing Causes Shoulder Pain.

3. Muscular imbalances

 The throwing muscles (anterior shoulder, chest muscles) often become stronger than the posterior
 stabilizers, reinforcing the imbalance.

 

 When adaptation becomes pathology

 When the posterior capsule becomes too tight, the rotation center in the shoulder shifts. This can lead
 to:

 
 Internal impingement: Rotator cuff tendons are pinched between the humeral head and
 labrum posterosuperiorly

 SLAP lesion: Traction pain at the biceps attachment
 

 Partial rotator cuff tear: Especially the undersurface of supraspinatus

 

 
 Risk factors for developing symptomatic GIRD

 
 Rapid increase in training volume or intensity

 Lack of periodization and recovery

 Insufficient warm-up

 Neglecting stretching and posterior strength

 Poor throwing technique

Forklar behandling for Spondylolistese: Glidning av virvler.

Behandling

 Konservativ behandling (førstevalg)

 De fleste med spondylolistese grad I-II responderer godt på konservativ behandling. Målet er å styrke stabiliserende muskulatur, bedre bevegelighet og redusere smerte.

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Manuell behandling: Forsiktig mobilisering og bløtvevsbehandling for å bedre bevegelighet og redusere muskelspenninger

 Stabiliserende øvelser: Kjernemuskeltrening tilpasset din tilstand

 Holdningsveiledning: Lære riktig teknikk for daglige aktiviteter

 Ergonomisk rådgivning: Tilpasninger på jobb og hjemme

 Viktige øvelser

 Bekkenvipper (pelvic tilts): Styrker dype magemusker og stabiliserer korsryggen

 Dead bug: Kjernemuskeltrening uten belastning av ryggen

 Bird dog: Balanse og kjernemuskelkontroll

 Planken: Statisk kjernemuskelstyrke

 Broøvelse: Styrker gluteus og bakside lærmuskler

 Unngå øvelser med ekstrem bakoverboying (ekstensjon) av ryggen.

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Hold deg aktiv: Moderat aktivitet er viktigere enn hvile

 Regelmessig trening: Fokus på kjernemuskelstyrke og fleksibilitet

 Vektkontroll: Overvekt øker belastningen på ryggen

 God ergonomi: Riktig sitte- og løfteteknikk

 Unngå provoserende aktiviteter: Reduser aktiviteter som gir mye bakoverboying

 Kirurgi

 Kirurgi vurderes kun når
 Konservativ behandling i 3-6 måneder ikke gir tilstrekkelig lindring

 Det er progressive nevrologiske symptomer

 Høygradige glidninger (grad III eller høyere)

 Betydelig nedsatt livskvalitet

 Operasjonstyper

 Dekompresjon: Fjerner vev som trykker på nerver. Fusjon: Stiver sammen virvlene for å hindre videre glidning. Ofte kombineres disse.

Assess red flags: 60-year-old male falls from ladder 3 meters. Cannot move legs. Numbness from navel down. Urinary incontinence.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute spinal cord compression.

Clinical reasoning:
- High-energy trauma (fall from height) + bilateral neurological deficits = spinal fracture with cord involvement
- Numbness from navel (T10 level) = complete sensory level
- Incontinent = sphincter involvement
- Bilateral paralysis = acute cord injury

This is a life-threatening emergency. Every minute counts.

ACTION: Call emergency services. FULLY immobilize patient. Do not move. Spinal immobilization. Urgent CT and MRI. Neurosurgical evaluation for emergency decompression.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Hodepine og svimmelhet.

Hva er kombinasjonen hodepine og svimmelhet?: Hodepine og svimmelhet er hver for seg blant de vanligste plagene folk oppsøker helsevesenet for. Når de opptrer samtidig, handler det sjelden om tilfeldigheter.

Årsaker - fra vanligst til sjeldnest: Vestibular migrene er den hyppigste årsaken til episodisk vertigo hos voksne, med en befolkningsprevalens på 0,9-2,7% (Formeister 2018). Blant migrenepasienter har 10,3% vestibular migrene.

Røde flagg - når du MA søke lege: Bakre skallegropsinfarkt (slag i hjernestamme/lillehjerne) feildiagnostiseres i 35-37% av tilfellene. De klassiske varseltegnene er de "5 D-er": Dizziness, Diplopi, Dysartri, Dysfagi og Dysmetri.

Diagnose: Kombinasjonen hodepine og svimmelhet krever grundig utredning for å skille mellom de ulike årsakene
Behandling: En systematisk gjennomgang av 4 randomiserte studier viser at manuell behandling har effekt på nakke-relatert svimmelhet. Studier viste signifikant bedring i svimmelhetsintensitet og -frekvens som vedvarte ved 12 måneders oppfølg.

Prognose: Med riktig behandling opplever de fleste betydelig bedring. Studier viser signifikant forbedring i svimmelhetsfrekvens og -intensitet ved 12 måneders oppfølg. Tilbakefall kan forekomme, særlig ved gjentatt belastning av nakken.

Ofte stilte spørsmål: Cefalalgi og vertigo forekommer tre ganger oftere sammen enn forventet statistisk. Over 51% av personer med residiverende cefalalgi rapporterer også vertigo (Lempert & Neuhauser 2009). De vanligste årsakene er vestibular migrene og cervikogen svimmelhet fra nakken.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Hallux Rigidus (Stiv Storta).

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan hallux rigidus bli bedre uten operasjon?

 Ja, mange opplever betydelig bedring med konservativ behandling, spesielt i tidlige stadier (grad 1-2). Mobilisering, riktig fottoy, innlegg og Øvelser kan redusere smerter og bedre funksjon vesentlig. Tilstanden blir ikke "kurert", men symptomene kan kontrolleres godt.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på hallux rigidus og hallux valgus?

 Hallux rigidus er artrose med stivhet i stortåens grunnledd - tøen forblir vanligvis rett, men blir stiv. Hallux valgus (kjulebein) er en feilstilling der stortåen bøyes mot de andre tårne og gir en kul på innsiden av foten. Begge kan gi smerter, men Årsakene og behandlingen er ulik.

 

 
 Hvilke sko er best ved hallux rigidus?

 Velg sko med stiv såle (rocker-sole), romslig tøboks og lav hæl. Skoene bør ikke bøyes mye ved stortåen. Unngå høyhelte sko og fleksible såler som tvinger leddet til å bøye seg. Spesialinnlegg (Morton's extension) kan våre nyttig.

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det for hallux rigidus blir verre?

 Progresjonen varierer sterkt fra person til person. Noen forblir stabile i mange Ør, mens andre opplever gradvis forverring over måneder til Ør. Tidlig behandling, aktivitetstilpasning og riktig fottoy kan bremse utviklingen betydelig.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med hallux rigidus?

 Ja, men velg aktiviteter som ikke belaster stortaens grunnledd for mye. Sykling og svomming er ofte gode alternativer. Unngå aktiviteter som krever kraftig avspark fra stortaen (loping...

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Osteoporose og kompresjonsfrakturer i ryggen.

Symptomer

 

 Her kommer en overraskende opplysning: 65-75 % av alle vertebrale frakturer gir ingen eller minimale symptomer (AAFP, 2016). Mange oppdages tilfeldig på røntgen eller MR tatt av andre Årsaker.

 Når symptomer oppstår, ser jeg ofte:

 
 Plutselig, intens smerte midt i ryggen eller i overgangen bryst-/korsrygg - lignende brystryggsmerter

 Smerten forverres ved stillingsendring, hosting eller løfting

 Bedring i hvile og liggende stilling

 Gradvis høydetap over tid

 Økende krumning av Øvre rygg (kyfose) - se krum rygg

 

 
 Det typiske scenarioet

 En eldre person, ofte kvinne, opplever plutselig kraftig ryggsmerte etter å ha bøyd seg ned eller løftet noe lett. Det var intet tydelig fall eller traume.

 

 Nyttige kliniske tegn

 To kliniske tegn har vist seg nyttige:

 
 Knyttneve-perkusjonstesten (å banke lett på virvelen) har sensitivitet på 87,5 % og spesifisitet på 90 %.

 "Supine sign" - at pasienten ikke klarer å ligge flatt med kun en pute på grunn av smerte - har sensitivitet 81 % og spesifisitet 93 % (PMC, 2011).

Behandling

 

 
 Prognose er god

 
 52% av milde tilfeller går over spontant

 63-80% blir bra med kortison

 Kirurgi har >90% suksessrate for resten

 
 

 Behandlingstrappen

 
 1. Avlastning og skinne

 Fingerortose som holder fingeren strakt om natten. Ofte nok for milde tilfeller.

 

 
 2. Kortison (Effektivt)

 Kortisoninjeksjon i seneskjeden har 63-80% suksessrate. Kan gjentas 1-2 ganger.

 

 
 3. Kirurgi

 A1-pulley release - en enkel dagkirurgisk prosedyre med >90% suksess.

 

 
 Sjokkbolgebehandling (ESWT)

 En systematisk oversikt fra Brancaccio et al. (2024) konkluderer at ESWT ikke har bevist effekt for triggerfinger. Ikke anbefalt som behandling.

Describe Limit Pain Medication in the context of Headache on Top of the Head.

Limit Pain Medication

 Avoid daily use of paracetamol or NSAIDs to prevent medication overuse headache.

 

 Treatment Course

 Dose-response studies for cervicogenic headache found that 8-10 treatments over 6 weeks was effective. For most patients, you can expect immediate relief after the first treatment, significant improvement after 4-8 weeks, and full effect after 6-8 weeks of treatment and exercises.

 

 
 
 
 6
 Prognosis

 

 Most people with headache on top of the head have a good prognosis. Tension headache and neck-related causes often respond well to treatment.

 Short-term

 Good probability of improvement with treatment - one study found that 72% of patients with cervicogenic headache maintained at least 50% reduction in headache frequency after 12 months.

 Relapses are Common

 Headache tends to return, especially with persistent risk factors like stress and static work. This does not mean treatment has failed - it means prevention and self-management are important.

 Long-term

 Evidence suggests that different treatments often give similar results over time. The most important factor for sustained improvement appears to be regular exercises and lifestyle changes.

 

 
 
 
 7
 Frequently Asked Questions

Describe diagnosis for Pain Behind the Shoulder.

Diagnosis

 Clinical examination

 Range of motion assessment: Compare internal rotation on both sides (GIRD)

 Infraspinatus test: External rotation against resistance

 Internal impingement test: Pain in abducted/externally rotated position

 total rotation range (internal + external) of >5 degrees.

Describe Solutions and Prevention for Text Neck and Jaw Pain: How Mobile Use Affects the Jaw.

Solutions and Prevention

 

 
 1. Change Mobile Habits

 
 Hold your phone higher: Raise it to eye level

 Limit time: Set limits on screen time

 Take breaks: 20-20-20 rule (every 20 min, look at something 20 m away for 20 sec)

 Alternate: Switch between holding the phone with right and left hand

 
 

 
 2. Optimize Your Workstation

 
 Screen height: Top edge at eye level

 Screen distance: One arm's length

 Chair: Back support and correct height

 Standing desk: Variation is good

 
 

 3. Exercises

 
 Chin Tuck

 
 Sit or stand straight

 Pull your chin straight back (like a "double chin")

 Hold for 5 seconds

 Repeat 10 times, several times daily

 
 

 
 Neck Stretch

 
 Gently tilt your head to the side (ear toward shoulder)

 Hold 20-30 seconds

 Repeat on the opposite side

 
 

 
 Chest Muscle Stretch

 
 Stand in a doorway with forearms against the frame

 Take a step forward

 Feel the stretch in your chest

 Hold 30 seconds

 
 

 
 Shoulder Blade Retraction

 
 Pull your shoulder blades together and down

 Hold 5 seconds

 Repeat 10 times

Hva er en stressfraktur?

 

 Bein er levende vev som stadig brytes ned og bygges opp. Når belastningen er større enn beinets kapasitet til å reparere seg, oppstar først en "stressreaksjon" - en forløper til fraktur. Describe The Jaw and Posture Are Connected for Breathing, Stress and Back.

The Jaw and Posture Are Connected

 

 What Does the Research Show?

 Numbers have circulated that "49% of people with poor posture have jaw problems." I found no scientific
 support for this after extensive searching.

 What is actually documented (Xiao et al., 2023) is a weak but statistically significant
 correlation between forward head posture and temporomandibular disorders (TMD). The correlation
 is r=0.16-0.23 - thus much weaker than the viral claims.

 More interesting is that 88.5% of TMD patients have at least one postural deviation (Di
 Francesco et al., 2023). Forward head posture is 2.4 times more common in people with muscular TMD than in
 controls (Cortese et al., 2017).

 
 What Does This Mean in Practice?

 The connection is likely bidirectional: Poor posture can contribute to jaw tension, and jaw tension can
 affect neck and head posture. For many patients, it makes sense to treat both simultaneously.

Beskriv diagnostikk for PCL.

Diagnostikk

 En grundig klinisk undersøkelse er avgjørende for å diagnostisere PCL-skade
 Kliniske tester

 Bakre skuff-test

 Hovedtest 

 Pasienten ligger med kneet bøyd 90 grader. Undersøkeren presser leggbenet bakover. Økt bevegelse sammenlignet med frisk side indikerer PCL-skade.

 Posterior sag sign

 Med kneet bøyd 90 grader ses det at leggbenet "henger" bakover sammenlignet med frisk side.

 Quadriceps active test

 Når pasienten strammer quadriceps, flytter leggbenet seg fremover ved PCL-skade.

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR: Gullstandard for å visualisere PCL og vurdere skadeomfang

 Røntgen: Utelukker brudd og kan vise "avulsjonsfraktur" der PCL har dratt med seg bein

 Stressrøntgen: Måler bakre forskyvning under belastning

 Viktig å vurdere

 PCL-skader forekommer ofte sammen med andre skader. Undersøkelsen bør også vurdere
 Bakre lateralt hjørne (posterolateral corner)

 Menisker 

 ACL og sideligamenter

Describe the two types of bruxism for Teeth Grinding.

The Two Types of Bruxism

 Sleep Bruxism

 This is the classic "nighttime teeth grinding" most people think of
 Rhythmic movements: The jaw moves in repetitive patterns

 Occurs in light sleep: Especially in transitions between sleep stages

 Enormous forces: Can generate 50-80 kg pressure - far above normal chewing force of 10-15 kg

 Sound: Partner often hears loud grinding noise

 Morning symptoms: Headache, sore jaw, tired chewing muscles

 Important: Sleep bruxism is classified as a sleep-related movement disorder and is often linked to other sleep problems.

 Awake Bruxism

 This type occurs while you're awake and is fundamentally different
 Static clenching: You press teeth together without movement

 Stress trigger: Triggered by concentration, stress , frustration

 Semi-conscious: You can learn to become aware of it

 Daytime symptoms: Jaw pain that increases throughout the day

 More common in women: Studies show higher prevalence

 Why the Distinction Matters

 Awake bruxism can be treated with awareness training and biofeedback - you can learn to stop. Sleep bruxism happens unconsciously and requires other approaches like sleep hygiene, stress management and protective measures.

Skriv henvisning til MR for cervikal radikulopati.

Til: Radiologisk avdeling
Fra: [Klinikknavn], kiropraktor
Dato: [dato]

Pasient: [Navn], [alder] år
Henvisningsgrunn: Cervikal radikulopati C6 høyre

Anamnese: 6 ukers sykehistorie med nakkesmerter og utstråling til høyre arm i C6-distribusjon (lateral underarm, tommel). VAS 6/10. Forverres ved cervikal ekstensjon og høyre rotasjon. Parestesier i tommel intermitterende.

Kliniske funn: Positiv Spurlings test høyre med utstråling til C6-dermatom. Svekket bicepsrefleks høyre (1+ vs 2+ venstre). Kraft: Biceps 4+/5 høyre. Sensibilitet: Lett nedsatt berøringssans laterale underarm og tommel høyre.

Konservativ behandling med manuell terapi og øvelser i 4 uker uten tilfredsstillende bedring.

Ønske: MR cervikalt for å vurdere diskpatologi og foraminal stenose C5-C6.

Hastegrad: Innen 2 uker (progredierende nevrologisk utfall).

Forklar behandling for Hodepine Etter Nakkesleng.

Behandling

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En Cochrane-oversikt fra 2007 gjennomgikk 23 studier med over 2300 deltakere. Hovedkonklusjonen var tydelig: Tidlig aktiv mobilisering er klart bedre enn hvile og nakkekrage.

 Vi bruker forsiktige teknikker tilpasset skadens fase
 Mobilisering: Myke teknikker for å gjenopprette bevegelse i løste ledd. Ved akutt nakkesleng unngår vi kraftig manipulasjon.

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Behandling av stramme muskler som forsøker å "beskytte" nakken.

 Vestibulær rehabilitering: Mange blir svimle etter nakkesleng. Vi gir øvelser for å trene opp balansen og samspillet mellom øyne, øre og nakke.

 En meta-analyse fra 2022 (Bini et al., Chiropractic & Manual Therapies) viste moderate til store korttidseffekter på hodepineintensitet ved cervikogen hodepine behandlet med manuell terapi.

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Helsenorge.no anbefaler at trening bør starte innen 4 dager etter skaden. Nakkekrage er unødvendig i de fleste tilfeller og kan faktisk forlenge symptomene hvis den brukes mer enn 48 timer.

 Tidlig bevegelse

 Gjentatte, forsiktige nakke- og hodebevegelser lindrer mer enn hvile.

 Dype nakkemuskler

 Øvelser for de dype nakkefleksorene er viktige. Disse musklene "skrus ofte av" etter whiplash, og de store overfladiske musklene tar over - noe som kan gi mer hodepine.

 Unngå passivitet

 De som holder seg i ro og bruker krage, har dobbelt så stor risiko for vedvarende symptomer som de som beveger seg tidlig (McKinney et al., 1989).

 Behandlingsforløp

 Det finnes ikke entydige retningslinjer for eksakt antall behandlinger ved nakkesleng. En systematisk oversikt (American Journal of PM&R, 2024) fant best resultater med minst 2 Økter per uke over minimum 6 uker.

Describe Exercise 2: Toe Spreading for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 2: Toe Spreading

 

 After years in narrow shoes, many have lost the ability to actively spread their toes. Toe spreading reactivates the abductor muscles and improves forefoot stability.

 
 How to Perform Toe Spreading

 
 Starting position: Sit or stand with your foot flat on the floor

 Movement: Spread the toes as far apart as possible

 Focus: Especially try to spread the big toe away from the others

 Hold: 5-10 seconds

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps

 Sets: 2-3 sets per foot

 
 

 
 Tip: Use Toe Spacers

 If you struggle to spread your toes, toe spacers can help. Use them passively while sitting or sleeping to gradually regain toe mobility. Start with 15-30 minutes and increase gradually.

Describe causes and risk factors for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Overload is the main cause

 PHT typically develops over time due to
 Too much, too fast - rapid increase in training load

 Compression + stretch - the tendon is squeezed against the bone with hip flexion

 Repetitive loading - running, cycling, rowing

 Prolonged sitting - constant pressure on the tendon

 Typical triggering activities

 Activities that increase risk

 Hill running - especially uphill

 Interval training - high speed demands

 Cycling - especially with low saddle height

 Yoga and Pilates - lots of hamstring stretching

 Rowing - repetitive hip flexion under load

 Biomechanical risk factors

 Weak gluteal muscles - gluteus must compensate (see also gluteal tendinopathy )

 Poor pelvic control - too much movement in the pelvis

 Stiff thoracic spine - compensatory movement in the pelvis

 Overstriding - too long stride length when running

Describe common causes of hip pain for Hip Pain?.

Common Causes of Hip Pain

 1 
 GTPS (Gluteal Tendinopathy)

 Previously misdiagnosed as "bursitis" - studies show that less than 5% actually have inflammation in the bursa. In 85-98%, the problem is in the gluteal tendons. This is the most common cause of pain on the outside of the hip.

 2 
 Hip Osteoarthritis

 Wear and tear in the hip joint, most common after 55-60. Causes gradually increasing stiffness, especially with internal rotation. Exercise is the first-choice treatment.

 3 
 FAI (Femoroacetabular Impingement)

 Pinching in the hip joint due to bone shape. Common in young, active people. 37% of pain-free people have FAI morphology on MRI - so images must be interpreted with caution.

 The MRI Trap

 MRI shows everything - including things that are normal age-related changes. 69% of pain-free people have labral tears on MRI. A "tear" doesn't necessarily mean it's the source of your pain. I treat people, not images.

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

3 Common Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 Most thoracic back pain is caused by mechanical issues that can be effectively treated by a chiropractor:

 
 Rib Joint Dysfunction (Costovertebral Dysfunction)

 The most common cause of thoracic back pain. Occurs when the joints between the ribs and vertebrae become stiff or "locked."

 
 Sharp pain with breathing and movement

 Point tenderness at the rib attachment

 Often triggered by twisting or lifting

 Responds very well to chiropractic treatment

 
 

 
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation in the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone. Causes pain at the front of the chest but often related to thoracic dysfunction.

 
 Tender to touch at the breastbone

 Can mimic heart pain

 Worse with coughing and deep breathing

 Often self-limiting, but treatment helps

 
 

 
 Thoracic Facet Joint Dysfunction

 Stiffness or irritation in the small joints between the vertebrae in the thoracic spine.

 
 Stiff and aching pain between the shoulder blades

 Worse with extension (bending backward)

 Often related to poor posture

 Common in office workers

 
 

 
 Myofascial Trigger Points

 Painful knots in the muscles, especially in the rhomboids, trapezius, and erector spinae.

 
 Often refer pain to other areas

 Can cause headaches and neck pain

 Often related to stress and overload

 Treated effectively with soft tissue treatment

 
 

 
 Poor Posture and Ergonomics

 Prolonged poor loading from office work, mobile phone use, or on...

Beskriv Den store forvekslingen for Bihulehodepine eller migrene?.

Den store forvekslingen

 

 
 
 88%
 har migrene, ikke bihulebetennelse
 

 
 8 Ør
 gjennomsnittlig feildiagnose
 

 
 12%
 unødvendig operert
 

 

 Tilsvarende funn kom i SAMS-studien fra 2007, hvor kun 3% av deltakerne faktisk hadde hodepine fra bihulebetennelse. Resten hadde migrene eller andre hodepinetyper.

 
 Hvorfor forveksles de?

 Trigeminusnerven forsyner både hjernehinnene (der migrene oppstår) og bihulene. Når migrene aktiverer denne nerven, utløses en refleks som gir tett nese, rennende Øyne og trykk i ansiktet - symptomer vi forbinder med forkjølelse eller bihulebetennelse.

 Studier viser at 40-74% av migrenepasienter opplever minst ett slikt "bihulelignende" symptom under anfall.

 

 
 Den kritiske forskjellen

 Migrene gir klar væske fra nesen (fra nerveaktivering)

 Bakteriell bihulebetennelse gir gulgrénn, tykk slim (fra infeksjon)

 Support neck and back with good chair and pillows

 Take breaks and do stretching exercises between feeding sessions

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Scheuermanns sykdom.

Scheuermanns sykdom er en vekstforstyrrelse i ryggsøylen som oppstar i puberteten. Under vekstspurten utvikler flere ryggvirvler seg ujevnt - den fremre delen vokser saktere enn den bakre. Resultatet er kileformede virvler som skaper en permanent, Økt krumning i brystryggen.

 Tilstanden ble først beskrevet av den danske ortoped Holger Werfel Scheuermann i 1920. Hans danske kollega Kaj Sorensen etablerte de diagnostiske kriteriene i 1964, som fortsatt brukes internasjonalt i dag.

Explain exercises you can do at home for Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Exercises You Can Do at Home

 Gaze Stabilization Exercises (VOR x1)

 Hold a finger or a letter at arm's length

 Focus on the target

 Move your head slowly from side to side while keeping your gaze on the target

 Start with 10 repetitions, 3 times daily

 Gradually increase speed over weeks

 Balance Exercises

 Level 1 - Romberg: Stand with feet together, arms at sides, hold for 30 seconds. Progression: Open eyes - Closed eyes - Soft surface

 Level 2 - Tandem stance: Stand with one foot in front of the other (heel-to-toe), hold for 30 seconds on each side

 Level 3 - Single leg stance: Stand on one leg, goal: 30 seconds on each side

 Important Principles

 Consistency is key: Daily practice gives better results than intense, sporadic training

Patient asks: "What is the difference between meralgia paresthetica and sciatica?"

Meralgia paresthetica affects the front/outer thigh and only causes sensory symptoms (numbness, tingling, burning). Sciatica affects the back of the leg, can go all the way to the foot, and can cause both pain and weakness. They are two completely different nerves.

Describe Types of Dizziness After Concussion for Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

Types of Dizziness After Concussion

 

 
 Crystal Dizziness (BPPV) - 10-57%

 Here, small calcium crystals have loosened from their normal position in the balance organ and ended up in the semicircular canals. Post-traumatic BPPV often behaves differently than regular BPPV - it more often affects multiple canals simultaneously and can be more resistant to treatment.

 

 
 Vestibulo-ocular Dysfunction - Over 50%

 Problems with the reflex that keeps your gaze stable when the head moves. Symptoms are often blurred vision during head movements, difficulty reading, and dizziness in visually demanding environments.

 

 
 Neck-Related Dizziness - 20-58%

 Occurs in people with whiplash and often appears together with vestibular complaints. The neck contains many sensitive receptors that give the brain information about head position.

Describe Strategies to Break the Cycle for Stress and Jaw Pain: How Stress Settles in the Jaw.

Strategies to Break the Cycle

 

 
 1. Awareness - The Most Important First Step

 You can't change something you're not aware of:

 
 Set reminders: Use your phone or post-it notes to remind yourself to check the jaw

 Body scanning: Several times daily - is the jaw relaxed?

 Trigger situations: Notice when you clench (screen work, driving, stressful conversations)

 
 

 
 2. Rest Position for the Jaw

 Teach your jaw a new default setting:

 
 "N technique": Say the letter "N" and hold the jaw in that position

 Mantra: "Lips together, teeth apart"

 Tongue: Rest against the palate, just behind the front teeth

 
 

 
 3. Breathing Techniques

 Breathing and jaw are closely connected:

 
 4-7-8 breathing: In for 4, hold for 7, out for 8

 Diaphragmatic breathing: Breathe deeply into the belly

 Breathe through the nose: Calmer than mouth breathing

 
 

 
 4. Progressive Muscle Relaxation

 
 Press teeth hard together for 5 seconds

 Release completely and feel the contrast

 Let the jaw hang heavy for 10 seconds

 Repeat 3-5 times

 
 By tensing first, you learn to feel the difference between tense and relaxed.

 

 
 5. General Stress Management

 
 Regular physical activity: Releases tension from the body

 Sleep hygiene: Stress and poor sleep reinforce each other

 Breaks: Short breaks throughout the workday

 Boundary setting: Say no to overload

 Mindfulness/meditation: Documented effect on stress response

Describe causes and risk factors for Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

Causes and Risk Factors

 The condition most often develops gradually as a result of overload and degeneration.

 Overweight

 Increased load on the tendon, especially with BMI over 25

 Female gender

 4 times more common in women, possible hormonal factor

 Age over 40

 The tendon naturally degenerates with age

 Diabetes

 Affects blood supply and tendon quality

 Hypertension

 Associated with reduced blood supply to the tendon

 Previous injury

 Ankle injuries and ankle instability can predispose to PTTD

 Athletes who engage in running, basketball or tennis can also develop the condition due
 to repeated loading. Load injuries can also affect the Achilles
 tendon and lead to stress fractures in the foot .

Describe diagnosis for Disc Herniation in the Lower Back.

Diagnosis

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination is the foundation for diagnosis.

 Straight Leg Raise (Lasegue)

 Sensitivity 92%, specificity 28% (Cochrane, 2010). High sensitivity means the test
 rarely misses a herniation. Positive when pain radiates below the knee with leg elevation between 30-70
 degrees.

 Crossed SLR

 Sensitivity 28%, specificity 90% (Cochrane, 2010). When this is positive, there is
 very high probability of herniation.

 Slump Test

 Sensitivity 84% . Performed sitting and combines neck flexion with knee extension.

 Imaging

 MRI is the gold standard for visualizing disc herniations. But an important point: Studies show that
 30-60% of pain-free people have disc changes visible on MRI. Therefore, it is the symptom
 picture - not the MRI finding alone - that determines the diagnosis.

 When is MRI Appropriate?

 MRI is usually considered after 4-6 weeks if symptoms don't improve with conservative treatment, or
 earlier with worsening neurological deficits.

Vurder røde flagg: 35 år mann med akutt korsryggsmerte og bilateral beinsvakhet. Problemer med vannlating.

AKUTT RØDT FLAGG - CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROM MISTANKE

Funn som gir mistanke:
1. Bilateral beinsvakhet - tyder på affeksjon av multiple nerverøtter
2. Blæredysfunksjon (vannlatingsproblemer) - kardinaltegn for cauda equina
3. Akutt debut - kan indikere stor diskprolaps eller annen romoppfyllende prosess

ANDRE SYMPTOMER Å SJEKKE UMIDDELBART:
- Sadel-anestesi (nummenhet perineum/genitalia)
- Nedsatt anal sphincter-tonus
- Seksuell dysfunksjon
- Bilateral sciatica

HANDLING:
- STOPP ALL BEHANDLING
- Ring 113 eller kjør pasienten til akuttmottak UMIDDELBART
- Cauda equina er en kirurgisk akuttsituasjon (dekompresjon innen 24-48 timer)
- Dokumenter funn og tidspunkt for symptomstart
- Informer akuttmottak om mistanke ved ankomst

Du er en medisinsk sikkerhetsrådgiver for kiropraktikk. Identifiser røde flagg, gi differensialdiagnostikk og klinisk resonnering. Prioriter alltid pasientsikkerhet. Klassifiser hastegrad: AKUTT (ring 113), HENVIS SAMME DAG, HENVIS RUTINE, MONITORÉR, eller TRYGT.

Vurder røde flagg: 45 år kvinne med kronisk nakkesmerte, følges regelmessig. I dag forteller hun om episoder med nummenhet og svakhet i høyre arm og ben som varer 10-15 minutter og går helt over. Har skjedd 3 ganger siste måneden. "Armen sovner bare."

HASTEGRAD: HENVIS SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig TIA (transitorisk iskemisk anfall) — feilattribuert til nakkeproblemer.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Kronisk nakkesmerte er separat, kjent tilstand
- MEN: episodisk, SAMTIDIG arm + ben svakhet på SAMME side = ikke cervikal radikulopati
- Cervikal radikulopati: gir arm-symptomer ALENE (unilevel), IKKE arm+ben
- Ipsilateral arm + ben (hemiparese) = sentral nervesystem-patologi
- Forbigående episoder (10-15 min) med full restitusjon = klassisk TIA
- TIA er forvarsel om slag (30% risiko innen 90 dager uten behandling)

HANDLING: IKKE utfør cervikal manipulasjon. Akuttmottak SAMME DAG. CT/MR cerebrum, CT-angiografi halskar, EKG. Nevrologisk vurdering. Antiplatelet-behandling kan bli aktuelt.

What are trigger points?

 

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle fibers - often described as "knots" or "tightness."
 When you press on a trigger point, it causes characteristic pain, and often also referred
 pain - pain that radiates to other areas.

 There are two main types:

 
 Active trigger points Cause symptoms

 Cause spontaneous pain and referred pain. Can disturb sleep and affect daily function.

 

 
 Latent trigger points

 Only tender when pressed. Can limit mobility and weaken the muscle, but don't cause spontaneous pain.

How Does It Differ from Other Types of Dizziness?: Cervicogenic dizziness typically feels like
Causes and Risk Factors: From most common to rarest
Diagnosis: Cervicogenic dizziness is a diagnosis of exclusion - other causes such as BPPV , vestibular hypofunction and PPPD must be ruled out first. There is no gold standard test, but the combination of medical history, clinical examination and specific tests provides good diagnostic accuracy.

The Chiropractor's Role with Red Flags

 In Norway, chiropractors have been primary contact practitioners with independent treatment and
 diagnostic authority since 2006. You can see a chiropractor directly without a referral from a doctor.

 What the Chiropractor Does

 Systematic screening for red flags as part of the initial examination

 Assessment of symptoms of cauda equina syndrome, infection, fracture, and malignancy

 Referral to specialist, hospital, or imaging when serious pathology is suspected

 Treatment of the 99%+ who have harmless back pain

 Chiropractors in Norway have referral rights to MRI, CT, X-ray, and ultrasound, as well as the right to
 issue sick leave for up to 12 weeks.

Hva er krystallsyke (BPPV)?

 

 Tilstanden er godartet - den skyldes ikke alvorlig sykdom - men kan være svært plagsom og påvirke dagliglivet betydelig.

 
 Hvor vanlig er det?

 Krystallsyke rammer rundt 2,4% av befolkningen i løpet av livet. I Norge tilsvarer det omtrent 80 000 nye tilfeller hvert år. Tilstanden er vanligst hos personer over 50 år, og kvinner rammes dobbelt så ofte som menn.

 Ved 80-årsalder har opptil 10% av befolkningen opplevd minst en episode. En norsk registerstudie viste at svimmelhet står for nesten 1% av alle langtidssykmeldinger.

Describe What is the combination of headache and dizziness? for Headache and Dizziness.

What is the combination of headache and dizziness?

 

 Headache and dizziness are each among the most common complaints people seek healthcare for. When they occur simultaneously, it is rarely coincidental.

 
 
 51%
 of headache patients have dizziness
 

 
 3x
 more often together than by chance
 

 
 8.4 years
 average diagnostic delay
 

 

 
 Why do they occur together?

 Headache and dizziness share many common nerve pathways and structures. Both migraine and the balance organ are closely connected to the brainstem. The neck contains many proprioceptors that communicate with both headache and balance centers in the brain.

Describe symptoms and signs of Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 

 Tension headache has characteristic features that distinguish it from other headache types. According to ICHD-3 criteria (International Headache Society 2018), at least two of the following must be present:

 
 Bilateral location - the pain sits on both sides of the head, often in the back of the head or forehead

 Pressing or tightening quality - not pulsating

 Mild to moderate intensity - you can usually continue with daily activities

 Not worsened by physical activity - walking stairs or light movement does not make it worse

 

 
 Important difference from migraine

 With tension headache, you typically do not experience nausea or vomiting. Light or sound sensitivity may occur, but never both at the same time.

 

 Tension Headache vs. Migraine

 Headache in the temple or top of the head can occur in both conditions, but the character is different.

Describe common causes of posterior shoulder pain for Pain Behind the Shoulder.

Common causes of posterior shoulder pain

 Infraspinatus tendinopathy

 Most common 

 Infraspinatus is one of four rotator cuff muscles and the second most common to
 injure . The muscle lies on the back of the shoulder blade and is responsible for external
 rotation of the shoulder.

 Pain behind the shoulder, may radiate toward the elbow

 Worsens with external rotation against resistance

 Often related to swimming, throwing and overhead activity

 Internal impingement

 Occurs when the rotator cuff (especially infraspinatus and supraspinatus) gets pinched against the
 posterior labrum when the arm is in "throwing position" (abducted and maximally externally rotated).

 Pain behind the shoulder in the "late cocking" phase of throwing

 Common in baseball pitchers, handball players, volleyball - similar mechanics as in thrower's shoulder 

 Can cause secondary damage to labrum and rotator cuff

 GIRD (Glenohumeral Internal Rotation Deficit)

 Deficit in internal rotation of the shoulder, common in throwing athletes. 72% of handball players
 have GIRD. Often caused by tightening of the posterior shoulder capsule.

 Reduced internal rotation compared to the opposite side

 Increased external rotation (as compensation)

 Increased risk of shoulder problems and injuries

 Other causes

 Teres minor tendinopathy: Similar picture to infraspinatus

 Posterior labrum injury: Often together with internal impingement, can develop
 into SLAP lesion 

 Quadrilateral space syndrome: Rare, but can cause radiation

 Referred pain: From neck (C5-C6 radiculopathy)

Cortisone Injection

 Can provide good pain relief during acute flare-ups. The effect is often temporary (weeks to months),
 but can be combined with activity modification for better long-term results.

 

 Surgery

 Surgery is considered only when conservative treatment over 3-6 months doesn't provide satisfactory
 improvement:

 
 Distal Clavicle Resection (Mumford Procedure)

 The outer end of the collarbone is removed to eliminate painful bone-on-bone contact. Can be done
 arthroscopically or open. Good results in those with indication.

 First choice: Night splint

 
 50-70% experience improvement with nightly use of wrist splint

 Manual therapy matches surgery short-term

 Nerve gliding exercises

 Myofascial release of forearm and hand

 Mobilization of wrist bones

 
 

 Treatment plan at Chiropractor Mads Finstad

 Guidance on proper use of wrist splint. Must be used every night for at least 3-4 weeks to evaluate

 Structured exercises that mobilize the median nerve through its path, to reduce adhesions and improve
 nerve mobility.

 

 
 3. Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of forearm, mobilization of wrist bones, and nerve gliding techniques.

 

 
 4. Ergonomic guidance

What is the prognosis for Pregnant with Back Pain? How a Chiropractor Can Help?

Prognosis - What to Expect?

 

 Most improve significantly after giving birth. A large Danish study found that 67-75% were
 symptom-free three months after delivery, and over 90% after two years.

 
 Important to Know

 Women with pain in all three pelvic joints have a poorer prognosis - about 20% still have

 Norwegian guidelines recommend specialized physiotherapy if complaints are not significantly
 better six weeks after delivery

Clinical summary of Vestibular Hypofunction: The Complete Guide.

Key Summary

 What it is: Reduced or lost function in the balance organ in the inner ear - either on one side (unilateral) or both sides (bilateral)

 Most common causes: Vestibular neuritis/virus (most common in unilateral), ototoxic medications (most common in bilateral), Meniere's disease - in 20-51% the cause remains unknown

 Treatment: Vestibular rehabilitation has strong evidence (APTA guidelines 2022). Unilateral: 4-6 weeks. Bilateral: 8-12 weeks or longer

 Red flags: Acute dizziness with headache/neck pain, speech difficulties, paralysis, double vision or numbness - call emergency services

Describe causes and risk factors for Hip Pointer.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Over 95% of all hip pointer injuries are caused by direct trauma to the iliac crest. The
 most common causes ranked by frequency
 Direct impact in contact sports - tackles in football, checking in ice hockey,
 collisions in handball or rugby

 Falls on the hip - cycling, skating, skiing, or general accidents

 Traffic accidents - rarer, but can cause more severe injuries

 Important for Adolescents

 In teenagers, the growth plate on the iliac crest (apophysis) is not fully developed until the 20s.
 This means what looks like a regular hip pointer in an adolescent could actually be an avulsion
 fracture where bone pulls away from the growth plate. Average age for such pelvic avulsion
 fractures is only 14.4 years.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Triggerpunkter og Myofascielt Smertesyndrom i Nakken.

Behandling

 

 
 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En nettverks-metaanalyse fra 2024 viser at manuell behandling gir korttidsbedring av smerte, trykkomfintlighet og funksjon.

 
 Ischemisk kompresjon: Vedvarende trykk på triggerpunktet gir signifikant bedring i trykksmerteterskel

 Dry needling: Tynne nåler settes direkte i triggerpunktet. Like effektivt som manuell triggerpunktbehandling på kort og mellomlang sikt

 Myofascielle teknikker og mobilisering: Bløtvevsbehandling av muskler og fascia

 Leddmobilisering/manipulasjon: Ved samtidig leddysfunksjon i nakke eller brystrygg

 
 

 
 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 En systematisk oversikt viser at kombinert tøying og styrketrening gir best effekt på myofascielle smerter:

 
 Tøying: Hold i 30 sekunder - dette er optimal varighet ifølge forskning. Tøy trapezius, levator scapulae og skalener daglig

 Styrketrening: Øvelser for dyp nakkemuskulatur og skulderbladsstabilisatorer

 Ergonomi: Skjerm i øyehøyde, underarmer støttet, regelmessige pauser. Unngå fremskutt hodestilling

 Selvmassasje: Bruk en tennisball eller lacrosseball mot veggen for forsiktig trykk på ømme punkter. 30-60 sekunder per punkt

 Stressmestring: Kronisk stress vedlikeholder muskelspenninger. Vurder pusteteknikker eller mindfulness

 
 

 
 Korttidseffektene av behandling er godt dokumentert. For varig effekt er det viktig å kombinere behandling med egentrening og å adressere underliggende faktorer som stress, ergonomi og søvn.

Hva er osteoporose og kompresjonsfrakturer?

 

 Norge ligger i verdenstoppen for hoftefrakturer, og benmassen i den norske befolkningen ser ut til å våre blant de laveste i Europå (NOREPOS, 2014). Kombinert med utbredt vitamin D-mangel - rundt 40 % av voksne nordmenn har for lave nivåer - skaper dette et sårbart utgangspunkt for mange eldre (HUNT-studien, 2014).

 
 Livstidsrisiko

 Livstidsrisikoen for vertebral fraktur ved 50-Ørsalder er 16-18 % for kvinner og 5-11 % for menn. Ved 80 Ør har opptil 40 % hatt minst en kompresjonsfraktur (NCBI StatPearls, 2024).

Explain Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know to a patient.

You wake up in the middle of the night with intense, throbbing pain in your shoulder. The pain is so
 severe that you can barely lift your arm. Perhaps you had mild symptoms for weeks or months before this,
 but suddenly it has become dramatically worse. If you experience general shoulder pain , there may be several possible causes.

 This is a classic presentation of calcific tendinitis in the resorptive phase - when the body actively
 breaks down the calcium deposit. Paradoxically, this intense pain is often a sign that the body is in
 the process of resolving the problem itself.

 Calcific tendinitis is a self-limiting condition where calcium deposits form in the tendons around the
 shoulder, most commonly the supraspinatus tendon. Although the symptoms can be very intense,
 80-99% of patients recover without surgery (Uhthoff & Loehr, 1997).
