Describe causes and risk factors for Metatarsalgia.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Metatarsalgia develops when the forefoot is exposed to abnormally high or prolonged loading.

 Common Causes

 Improper Footwear Most common cause 

 High-heeled shoes, too tight shoes, or shoes without adequate cushioning significantly increase the
 load on the forefoot.

 Biomechanical Factors

 High arch (pes cavus), stiff ankle, long 2nd toe (Morton's toe), or hypermobile joints can lead to
 uneven load distribution.

 Overuse

 Too rapid increase in activity, prolonged standing work, or intensive running training can overload the
 forefoot.

 Hallux Valgus Often
 concurrent 

 A crooked big toe causes weight to shift to the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal, which become overloaded. Hallux rigidus can cause similar loading changes.

 Risk Factors

 Overweight (increased load per step)

 Age over 50 (thinner fat pads under the foot)

 High heels (shift weight forward)

 Diabetes (altered sensation and blood flow)

 Rheumatoid arthritis

 Sports with lots of running and jumping - can also lead to Achilles tendinopathy or stress fracture

Describe Why Do You Get So Tired? for Subtle BPPV: When Dizziness Doesn't Spin.

Why Do You Get So Tired?

 

 When the balance organ sends incorrect signals, the brain must work overtime to compensate. This process - vestibular compensation - requires significant neural resources.

 
 Compensation Timeline

 According to research from 2016, it takes up to 3 months for postural compensation (posture and stability), and up to 1 year for perception of vertical to normalize.

 

 
 The consequence? 75% of patients with chronic BPPV were on 50-100% sick leave in one study (median illness duration over 5 years before adequate treatment).

Differential diagnoses for Metatarsalgia?

Improper Footwear Most common cause 

 High-heeled shoes, too tight shoes, or shoes without adequate cushioning significantly increase the

Biomechanical Factors

 High arch (pes cavus), stiff ankle, long 2nd toe (Morton's toe), or hypermobile joints can lead to
 uneven load distribution.

Overuse

 Too rapid increase in activity, prolonged standing work, or intensive running training can overload the
 forefoot.

Hallux Valgus Often
 concurrent 

 A crooked big toe causes weight to shift to the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal, which become overloaded. Hallux rigidus can cause similar loading changes.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Back, Hip or Sciatica?.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if the pain is coming from my back or hip?

 Hip pain is typically felt in the groin and front of the thigh,
 and worsens with hip rotation. Back pain often sits lower in the back and can
 radiate down the back of the leg. Bending forward often worsens back pain, while hip
 flexion worsens hip pain. A clinical examination is necessary for accurate
 diagnosis.

 

 
 Can I have both back and hip problems at the same time?

 Yes, this is actually common and is called "hip-spine syndrome".
 Studies show that up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis also have
 significant spinal disease. The problems can also affect each other - hip problems
 can change gait and put more stress on the back, and vice versa.

 

 
 What is the difference between sciatica and piriformis
 syndrome?

 Sciatica is caused by compression of the nerve root in the spine
 (often from a disc herniation), while piriformis syndrome is caused by compression
 of the sciatic nerve where it passes through the buttock muscles. The symptoms can
 be similar, but piriformis syndrome rarely causes neurological deficits and often
 worsens with prolonged sitting.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI to find out what's wrong?

 Not necessarily. A thorough clinical examination can often
 distinguish between back and hip problems. MRI is indicated when there is suspicion
 of serious pathology, neurological deficits, or when conservative treatment doesn't
 improve symptoms after 6-8 w...

How is Meniere's Disease diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 There is no single test that can confirm Meniere's disease. The diagnosis is made clinically based on international criteria (Barany Society/AAO-HNS, 2015/2020). It is important to distinguish Meniere's from other conditions such as vestibular migraine, vestibular neuritis and BPPV (crystal disease).

 Criteria for Definite Meniere's Disease:

 
 At least two spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting 20 minutes to 12 hours

 Audiometrically documented low- to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear

 Fluctuating symptoms (hearing loss, tinnitus or pressure sensation) in the affected ear

 Other causes excluded

 

 
 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for:

 
 Sudden, total hearing loss

 Dizziness with double vision, swallowing or speech difficulties

 Fainting or loss of consciousness

 Severe headache with dizziness

 High fever with dizziness and ear symptoms

 Frequent falls without warning (drop attacks)

Forklar Medikamentoverforbrukshodepine for en pasient.

Det startet som vanlig migrene eller spenningshodepine. Du tok en Paracet eller Ibux når smerten kom, og det hjalp. Men gradvis måtte du ta det oftere. Nå tar du smertestillende nesten hver dag - og hodepinen er der likevel, hele tiden.

 Hvis dette høres kjent ut, kan du ha utviklet medikamentoverforbrukshodepine (MOH) . Dette er en av de vanligste, men minst kjente formene for kronisk hodepine - og den gode nyheten er at den er behandlingsbar.

 Her får du vite hvordan MOH utvikles, hvordan du gjenkjenner det, og viktigst av alt: hvordan du kan bryte den onde sirkelen.

What is the prognosis for Kyphosis and Poor Posture?

Prognosis

 

 The prognosis for functional kyphosis is generally good with active treatment. Meta-analyses show that
 structured exercise programs can reduce kyphosis angle by 5-13 degrees over 8-12 weeks. Younger patients
 show better response than older ones.

 Important to know: Improvements require maintenance. Without continued exercise, most
 will gradually return to previous posture patterns. Therefore, home exercises and awareness of daily
 habits are crucial for long-term results.

 With structural kyphosis (Scheuermann's disease, osteoporosis), the prognosis is more variable and depends on severity.
 These conditions cannot be reversed, but function and quality of life can often be significantly improved.

Assess red flags: 70-year-old male with gradual difficulty with fine motor tasks (buttons, coins). Osteoarthritis in fingers bilaterally. Heberden nodes. Normal gait. Normal reflexes. Normal sensation.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why fine motor difficulty is NOT myelopathy here:
- Osteoarthritis in fingers with Heberden nodes = DEGENERATIVE cause of clumsy fingers
- Myelopathy: fine motor impairment + GAIT DISTURBANCE + hyperreflexia
- Normal gait (myelopathy causes ataxic/spastic gait)
- Normal reflexes (myelopathy causes hyperreflexia)
- Normal sensation (myelopathy often causes sensory changes)
- Isolated fine motor problem with visible joint changes = arthritis

Clinical picture: Finger osteoarthritis with mechanical functional limitation.

Safe to treat with hand exercises, heat therapy, ergonomic adaptation.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Svimmelhet?

Krystallsyke (BPPV)

 17-42% av tilfellene 

 Gå til full artikkel om krystallsyke (BPPV) → 

 Krystallsyke er den vanligste årsaken til svimmelhet som utredes i klinikker (Bosner, BMC Fam Pract, 2018). Tilstanden oppstår når små kalsiumkrystaller løsner fra sin plass i balanseorganet og havner i buegangene.

 Kjennetegn
 Korte, intense spinnanfall (10-60 sekunder)

 Utløses av bestemte hodebevegelser - snu seg i sengen, se opp, bøye seg ned

 Kvalme under anfallene

 Symptomfri mellom anfallene

Vestibular migrene

 ca. 1-3% av befolkningen 

 Gå til full artikkel om vestibular migrene → 

 Livstidsprevalens på rundt 1%, men nyere amerikanske data antyder opptil 2,7% (Formeister, Otol Neurotol, 2018). Barany Society har identifisert dette som "den desidert vanligste årsaken" til kombinerte nakkesmerter og Vestibulære symptomer. Kan forekomme med eller uten hodepine.

Vestibularisnevritt

 3-10% i svimmelhetsklinikker 

 Gå til full artikkel om vestibularisnevritt → 

 Årlig insidens på 3,5-7 per 100 000 (Iwasaki, Auris Nasus Larynx, 2024). Utgjør 3-10% av diagnosene i spesialiserte svimmelhetsklinikker. Viral betennelse av balansenerven som gir plutselig, intens svimmelhet over flere dager. Hørselen påvirkes ikke. 10-15% utvikler BPPV etterpå.

Ortostatisk hypotensjon

 Fall i blodtrykket når du reiser deg som midlertidig reduserer blodtilførsel til hjernen. Gir svartning for øynene og kort svimmelhet. Vanligvis ufarlig og bedres ved å reise seg saktere.

Cervikogen svimmelhet

 Gå til full artikkel om nakkesvimmelhet → 

 Her må man våre årlig: Cervikogen svimmelhet er kontroversiell. Barany Society publiserte i 2022 et standpunkt der de "avstar fra å foreslå diagnostiske kriterier for klinisk bruk" på grunn av manglende dokumentasjon for en mekanistisk kobling.

 De peker på at 68% av befolkningen rapporterer cervikalgi årlig, og 11-20% rapporterer balansesymptomer. Mye overlapping skjer rent tilfeldig.

Hva er POTS?

 

 POTS tilhorer gruppen dysautonomier - tilstander der det autonome nervesystemet ikke fungerer som det skal. Det autonome nervesystemet styrer funksjoner man normalt ikke tenker over: puls, blodtrykk, svette, fordoyelse og temperaturregulering.

 Når du reiser deg, trekker tyngdekraften 500-800 ml blod ned mot bena og magen. Normalt oppdager sensorer i halspulsaren dette og sender signal til hjernen om å Øke pulsen litt og stramme blodØrene i bena. Ved POTS fungerer ikke denne mekanismen som den skal.

Osteofytter

 Benpåleiring som vokser inn i ryggkanalen eller nerveutgangene.

 

 Risikofaktorer med dokumentert sammenheng

 
 Alder over 60 Ør: 3-5 ganger høyere forekomst

 Fedme: BMI over 30 gir mer enn dobbelt så høy risiko

 Diabetes: Finnes hos 29% av stenosepasienter mot 10% i normalbefolkningen

 Spondylolistese: Glidning av virvel kan bidra til stenose

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptomer

 

 Det klassiske symptomet ved lumbal spinal stenose kalles nevrogen claudicatio - et begrep som beskriver det typiske mønsteret mange opplever:

 
 Smerter, tyngdefølelse eller nummenhet i ett eller begge bein

 Symptomene kommer gradvis når du går eller star oppreist

 Lindring ved å sette deg ned, bøye deg fremover eller lene deg på en handlevogn

 Ofte bedre å sykle enn å gå (fordi du sitter litt fremoverlent)

 

 Disse symptomene kan minne om isjias, men ved stenose er mønsteret typisk at symptomene forverres ved gange og bedres ved hvile i fremoverlent stilling.

 
 Handlevogn-tegnet

 Dette er så karakteristisk at det brukes diagnostisk verden over. Mange pasienter forteller at de kan gå mye lenger når de støtter seg på en handlevogn. Dette skyldes at fremoverleaning utvider ryggkanalen og gir mer plass til nervene.

Describe Disc Herniation – When the Disc Bulges Out for Lower Back Pain – Complete Guide.

Disc Herniation – When the Disc Bulges Out

 

 Go to full article on disc herniation ?

 A disc herniation occurs when the soft core of the intervertebral disc pushes through the outer ring and can press on nerve roots. Only 5–15% of patients with lower back pain have lumbar disc herniation (OAMJMS, 2022).

 
 Important to Know About Disc Herniation

 Many people have disc herniations on MRI without symptoms å the finding alone doesn't mean you need treatment. 29% of 20-year-olds and 43% of 80-year-olds without pain have protrusion on MRI (Brinjikji, 2015).

 

 
 Can a Disc Herniation Heal On Its Own?

 Yes! The body has a remarkable ability to reabsorb herniated disc material: 66–77% of herniations are spontaneously reabsorbed over time (Zhong et al., 2017). The larger the herniation, the greater the chance of resorption.

 

 Treatment of Disc Herniation

 
 Conservative Treatment (First Choice)

 
 Manual therapy adapted to the condition

 McKenzie approach for centralizing symptoms

 Gradual increase in activity and exercises

 
 

 
 Surgery is Considered For:

 
 Cauda equina syndrome (emergency)

 Progressive neurological deficit

 Persistent symptoms after 6–12 weeks of conservative treatment

 
 

 ? Read complete article on disc herniation (spontaneous resorption, treatment and prognosis)

- Degenerative facettleddsforandringer
- Sagittal diameter <10mm på L4-L5

Konservativ behandling:
- Fysioterapi med fleksjonsprogram: Begrenset effekt
- Epidural injeksjon: Forbigående effekt

Ber om nevrokirurgisk vurdering med tanke på operativ dekompresjon.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Superior Kanal Dehiscens Syndrom.

Hvorfor gir hullet symptomer?: Det indre øret har normalt to "vinduer" - det ovale vindu der lyd kommer inn, og det runde vindu som gir trykkutligning. Når det oppstår et hull i buegangen, skapes et unormalt "tredje vindu" som endrer hvordan lyd og trykk påvirker balanseorganet.

Hvem rammes?: SCDS debuterer typisk i 40-60 Ørs alder (gjennomsnitt 50 år) og rammer kvinner litt oftere enn menn med et forhold på ca. 1,2:1. Anatomisk dehiscens er bilateral (begge sider) hos opptil 50% av pasientene, men vanligvis er ett øre mer symptomatisk enn det andre.

Symptomer: Forekommer hos 42-43% av pasientene. Høye lyder (typisk 500 Hz-2 kHz ved 100-110 dB) utløser roterende svimmelhet eller ustøhet. Eksempler kan vare høy musikk, hunder som bjeffer, eller stoy fra byggearbeid.

Differensialdiagnoser - hva kan ligne?: SCDS kalles "orets store etterligner" fordi symptomene kan ligne flere andre tilstander
Diagnostikk: Ved mistanke om SCDS kan folgende spørsmål vare avslorende
Behandling: For pasienter med milde til moderate symptomer er konservativ behandling ofte førstevalg. Ca. 80% av diagnostiserte pasienter gjennomgår ikke kirurgi. Konservative tiltak inkluderer
Kiropraktorens rolle ved SCDS: SCDS er en strukturell tilstand som krever spesialistvurdering og eventuelt kirurgisk behandling. Kiropraktoren kan ikke behandle selve tilstanden, men har en viktig rolle i identifisering og henvisning til ONH-spesialist.

Prognose og livskvalitet: Livskvaliteten ved SCDS er betydelig redusert for behandling. Health Utility Values hos preoperative pasienter er 0,68 mot 0,80 i normalbefolkningen. Dizziness Handicap Inventory viser gjennomsnitt 44 poeng, tilsvarende moderat handikap.

Hva forårsaker Triggerpunkter i Nakken - Muskelknuter og Referert Smerte?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Triggerpunkter utvikles når muskelfibre blir overbelastet eller skadet. De vanligste Årsakene, rangert etter hvor ofte vi ser dem:

 
 Statisk belastning og dårlig ergonomi (vanligst)

 Langvarig skrivebordsarbeid, skjermbruk med fremskutt hode, og ensidig arbeid er de klart vanligste Årsakene. Kontorarbeidere og manuelt arbeidende har tilsvarende triggerpunktfordeling, med gjennomsnittlig 6 aktive og 10-11 latente triggerpunkter (Fernandez-De-Las-Penas 2012).

 

 
 Muskulær overbelastning

 Repetitive bevegelser, tunge løft, eller plutselig Økt treningsbelastning.

 

 
 Stress og anspenthet

 Psykisk stress fører ofte til kronisk muskelspenning, særlig i nakke og skuldre.

 

 
 Andre faktorer

 
 Søvnproblemer og utmattelse: Dårlig søvn reduserer musklenes evne til restitusjon

 Vitamin D-mangel: Omtrent en tredjedel av MPS-pasienter har lave D-vitaminnivåer (StatPearls 2025)

 Traumer: Whiplash og andre skader. Blant whiplash-pasienter har 55-65% triggerpunkter i levator scapulae

 
 

 
 Hvem rammes?

 MPS forekommer oftest i aldersgruppen 27-50 Ør. Kvinner rammes oftere enn menn - 65% mot 37% blant middelaldrende voksne (Steen, Muscle & Nerve 2025).

Beskriv diagnostikk for Nociplastisk smerte: Når nervesystemet blir overfølsomt.

Diagnostikk

 Det finnes ingen enkel test for nociplastisk smerte. Diagnosen stilles klinisk basert på sykehistorie, symptommønster og utelukkelse av andre årsaker.

 Klinisk vurdering

 Grundig sykehistorie med fokus på symptomutvikling over tid

 Kartlegging av smertelokalisasjon og spredning

 Vurdering av sensoriske fenomener (allodyni, hyperalgesi)

 Screening for angst, depresjon og søvnforstyrrelser

 Nevrologisk undersøkelse for å utelukke nerveskade

 Standardiserte spårreskjemaer

 Central Sensitization Inventory (CSI)

 Et validert spårreskjema med 25 spørsmål som kartlegger symptomer assosiert med sentral sensitisering. Skøre over 40 av 100 indikerer sannsynlig sentral sensitisering.

 Pain Catastrophizing Scale

 Kartlegger grad av katastrofetenkning rundt smerte, som er assosiert med sentral sensitisering.

 Bildediagnostikk

 Viktig å vite

 MR og røntgen kan ikke påvise nociplastisk smerte. Bildediagnostikk brukes primært for å utelukke andre årsaker (røde flagg, nervekompresjon etc.). Funn som diskusdegenerasjon og artrose er vanlige også hos smertefrie personer og forklarer ikke nociplastisk smerte.

How is Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture diagnosed?

Diagnostics

 

 Many believe that X-ray is the definitive answer for detecting rib fractures. The truth is more nuanced.
 

 Imaging for Rib Fractures

 
 X-ray has surprisingly low accuracy

 Standard X-ray has only about 50% sensitivity (StatPearls, 2024). This means that approximately half of
 all rib fractures are not visible on X-ray because the fracture surfaces remain in place.

 Oslo Emergency Department's handbook (2018) states that rib fractures are "primarily a clinical
 diagnosis." X-ray is not required for uncomplicated cases - the diagnosis is made based on medical
 history and examination.

 

 When imaging is necessary: When lung complications are suspected (pneumothorax,
 hemothorax), with high-energy trauma, or with more than three consecutive fractures. CT or ultrasound
 provide much better accuracy than X-ray.

 Imaging for Rib Dislocation

 For rib dislocation, imaging is usually unnecessary. The condition is not visible on X-ray or MRI. The
 diagnosis is made clinically through examination of joint mobility, palpation tenderness, and pain
 provocation.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Overpronation: Myth or Medical Fact?.

A Diagnosis Born in the Shower: The story of overpronation begins in 1954, in a shower in California. Dr. Merton Root, a podiatrist, observed his own feet and developed a theory that there is an ideal foot position - what he called subtalar neutral.

Dr. Benno Nigg: From Believer to Skeptic: Dr. Benno Nigg is perhaps the world's most respected researcher in biomechanics and running shoes. He founded the Human Performance Laboratory at the University of Calgary and has studied running movements for over 40 years.

Pronators Have Fewer Injuries: In 2013, Nielsen and colleagues published a study in the British Journal of Sports Medicine that turned the overpronation myth on its head.

The Wet Test is Debunked: The wet test - where you stand on wet paper to see your footprint - has been the basis for assigning running shoes for decades. Flat footprint? Then you need motion control shoes. High arch? Then you need cushioning.

What is Pronation Really?: Pronation is a natural rotational movement in the foot that occurs when you land during walking or running. The foot rolls inward, and the arch flattens somewhat. This is not a flaw - it is the body's built-in shock absorption system.

Elite Athletes with "Problematic" Feet: If overpronation and flat feet were really so harmful, we would expect elite athletes to have perfect feet. But reality is quite different.

Why Does the Myth Persist?: Despite lack of scientific support, the overpronation concept continues to dominate. Why?

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor: Even though overpronation is not a valid diagnosis, there are real foot problems that require medical evaluation. Persistent pain should always be examined by a professional.

Describe The Most Common Jaw Conditions for Jaw Joint Problems (TMD) – Complete Guide.

The Most Common Jaw Conditions

 

 I've written detailed articles about the most common jaw conditions. Here's an overview:

 
 
 
 Condition
 What is it about?
 
 
 
 
 Trigger points in the jaw (37-45%)
 Most common cause of jaw pain. Tender points in the muscles that send pain to teeth, ear or
 temple.
 
 
 Clicking in the jaw (30%)
 Sounds from the jaw joint when yawning or chewing. Usually completely harmless –33% of
 symptom-free people have it.
 
 
 Bruxism and teeth grinding (22%)
 Night-time grinding or jaw clenching during the day. Can cause morning stiffness, headache and
 tooth wear.
 
 
 Lock jaw (2-8%)
 Limited mouth opening when the joint disc blocks movement. 95% get better within 12 weeks.
 
 
 Jaw joint osteoarthritis (8-16%)
 Wear in the joint causing grinding sounds and stiffness. Most common over 45 years. Often
 stabilises by itself.

Hva forårsaker Styrkeøvelser for korsryggen: Bygg en sterkere rygg?

Grunnleggende øvelser (start her)

 

 
 1. Dead bug

 Mål: Dyp kjernestabilitet

 
 Ligg på ryggen med armene opp og bena i 90 grader

 Press korsryggen flatt mot gulvet

 Senk langsomt motsatt arm og ben mot gulvet

 Hold korsryggen stabil hele tiden

 Tilbake til start, bytt side

 10-15 repetisjoner hver side

 
 

 
 2. Bird-dog

 Mål: Ryggstrekker og stabilitet

 
 Stå på alle fire, nøytral rygg

 Strekk ut motsatt arm og ben horisontalt

 Hold i 3-5 sekunder

 Bytt side uten å svaie i ryggen

 10-12 repetisjoner hver side

 
 

 
 3. Glute bridge

 Mål: Setemuskulatur og hoftestrekkere

 
 Ligg på ryggen med bøyde knær, føtter i gulvet

 Spenn setemusklene og løft hoftene

 Lag en rett linje fra skulder til kne

 Hold i 2-3 sekunder

 Senk kontrollert ned

 15-20 repetisjoner

 
 

 
 4. Planke

 Mål: Total kjernestabilitet

 
 Støtt på underarmene og tærne

 Kroppen rett som en planke

 Spenn mage og sete

 Hold så lenge du kan med god teknikk

 Mål: 30-60 sekunder

 
 

 
 5. Sideliggende planke

 Mål: Skrå bukmuskler og sidestabilitet

 
 Ligg på siden, støtt på underarmen

 Løft hoftene opp fra gulvet

 Hold kroppen i en rett linje

 Hold 20-30 sekunder

 Bytt side

Vurder røde flagg: 34 år mann med residiverende korsryggsmerte. Ny episode med bilateral beinsmerte. Oppdager nummenhet i indre lår bilateralt. Startproblemer ved vannlating siste 2 dager.

AKUTT: Tidlig cauda equina syndrom — inkomplett. Bilateral medial lårparestesi (sadelanestesi-distribusjon) med blærehesitasjon. Inkomplett CES har bedre prognose ved rask intervensjon. Ring 113. Akutt MR og nevrokirurgisk henvisning innen 24 timer.

Describe Breathing exercises in the context of Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

Breathing exercises

 Deep diaphragmatic breathing activates the parasympathetic nervous system and reduces muscle tension.
 Breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, breathe out for 6 seconds. Repeat for 5 minutes.

 

 Stress management

 For lasting improvement, underlying stress often needs to be addressed:

 
 Regular physical activity

 Adequate sleep (7-9 hours)

 Relaxation techniques (meditation, yoga)

 Social support and work-life balance

 If needed: Professional help for stress management

 

 
 Prognosis

 Most people experience good improvement with treatment. The challenge often lies in preventing
 relapse, which requires ongoing focus on ergonomics, exercises and stress management.

What is the prognosis for Runner's Knee (PFPS) - How to Return to Full Distance?

Prognosis - An Honest Picture

 

 Most people with runner's knee get better, but it takes time:

 
 
 6-12
 weeks to significant improvement
 

 
 40%
 have some symptoms after 1 year
 

 
 80%+
 return to running
 

 

 
 Important to be realistic

 Research shows that 40% still have some symptoms after 1 year. This doesn't mean
 they can't run - but that complete symptom resolution can take time. Patience and consistent training
 are key.

 

 Factors for better prognosis

 
 Shorter duration of symptoms before treatment starts

 Good adherence to exercise program

 Addressing hip weakness

 Gradual training progression

Identify red flags for Back, Hip or Sciatica?:

A Common and Complex Picture

 Up to 30% of patients with hip osteoarthritis have simultaneous
 significant spinal disease. This is called "hip-spine syndrome" and complicates both
 diagnosis and treatment.

 Why Does This Occur?

 
 Biomechanical coupling: A stiff hip increases load on the back
 

 Compensatory patterns: Altered gait affects the entire kinetic
 chain

 Common risk factors: Age, overweight, physical inactivity

 Sensitization: Chronic pain can make the entire region
 hypersensitive

 

 Treatment Implications:

 When both back and hip are involved, both must be addressed to achieve improvement. A
 hip replacement, for example, cannot solve a simultaneous back problem, and vice
 versa.

Forklar kombiner med fottrening for Ortose.

Kombiner med fottrening

 Nedtrapping uten fottrening er som å fjerne krykker uten fysioterapi. Kombinasjonen er avgjorende for suksess.

 Minimumsprogram - daglig

 Barfot-tid: Minst 30 minutter daglig innendors uten sko

 Short foot-ovelse: 3 sett x 10-15 repetisjoner - aktiver fotbuen uten å krumme tårne

 TØrspredning: Sprik tårne aktivt - hold 5 sekunder, 10 ganger

 Utvidet program - 3x/uke

 TØrgrep: Plukk opp sma gjenstander med tårne

 Halbev: 3 sett x 15 repetisjoner - start på gulv, progresjon til trapp

 Enbensstaaende: 3 x 30 sekunder per fot

 TØrgang: Gå på tær og haeler, 2 minutter hver

 Liverpool-studien (Curtis 2021)

 Deltakere som brukte minimalistsko daglig i 6 maneder okte fotstyrken med 57,4% - uten spesifikke øvelser. Kombinert med målrettet trening kan resultatene bli enda bedre.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can the SI joint really "go out of place"?

 No, the SI joint cannot physically go out of place. It is one of the body's most
 stable joints with very strong ligaments. What happens is that the joint becomes irritated, stiff or
 develops altered movement - not that it moves. The term "pelvic locking" is colloquially used but is not
 medically correct.

 

 
 Why does manipulation help when the joint is not out of place?

 Manipulation affects the nervous system and muscles around the joint. It can
 reduce pain, decrease muscle tension and restore normal movement in a stiff joint. The effect is
 neurological and biomechanical - not that something is "put back in place".

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 Most people with acute SI joint problems improve significantly within 4-8 weeks
 with proper treatment. Chronic cases may take longer. Maintenance exercises are important to prevent
 recurrence.

 

 
 Should I use an SI belt?

 An SI belt can provide temporary support in the acute phase, but should not be
 used for long periods. The goal is to build up the body's own stability through exercise, not to become
 dependent on external support.

 

 
 Can I exercise with SI joint pain?

 Yes, adapted exercise is important! Avoid exercises that provoke pain, but stay
 active. Swimming, walking and specific stabilization exercises are often well tolerated. Your
 chiropractor can give you an individually tailored program.

Describe Return-to-Sport for Hip Sports Injuries.

Return-to-Sport

 

 A gradual, criteria-based return to sport significantly reduces the risk of re-injury. Here
 are the typical phases:

 
 
 Acute Phase (0-72 hours): PRICE, pain control, diagnosis

 Subacute Phase (3 days - 2 weeks): Pain-free movement, light
 strength training, maintain fitness

 Rehabilitation Phase (2-6 weeks): Progressive strength training,
 mobility training, functional training

 Return-to-Sport Phase: Sport-specific training, gradual increase in
 intensity, functional tests

 Full Activity: Training and competition without restrictions,
 maintenance program

Describe Overuse Injuries in the context of Sports Injuries - Complete Guide.

Overuse Injuries

 Develop gradually from repetitive stress over time. Examples include tendinopathies (Achilles, patellar), stress fractures, and shin splints. Pain often starts mild and worsens if training continues unchanged.

 

 Common Sports Injuries

 
 Muscle strains: Tears in muscle fibers, often in hamstrings, quads, or calves

 Ligament sprains: Stretching or tearing of ligaments, commonly ankle or knee

 Tendinopathies: Degeneration of tendons from repetitive loading

 Stress fractures: Small cracks in bone from cumulative overload

 Joint injuries: Cartilage damage, labral tears, meniscus injuries

 
 

 
 
 
 2
 Causes and Risk Factors

Assess red flags: 55-year-old male with acute, extremely painful, red and swollen knee. Fever 38.5C. Cannot weight-bear. No preceding trauma.

URGENCY: REFER SAME-DAY (emergency department)

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Acute monoarthritis — septic arthritis until proven otherwise.

Clinical reasoning:
- Acute monoarthritis with fever = septic arthritis FIRST in differential
- Redness + swelling + warmth + pain + loss of function = classic acute inflammation
- Septic arthritis is a SURGICAL EMERGENCY (joint washout)
- Gout can look similar, but delayed treatment of septic arthritis = joint destruction
- Rule: "Hot, swollen joint with fever = joint aspiration FIRST"
- Joint aspiration distinguishes septic arthritis from crystal arthritis (gout)

ACTION: Emergency department SAME DAY. Joint aspiration for culture and crystal analysis. Blood cultures. Do NOT give antibiotics before samples taken. NO manual treatment of the joint.

Describe why can't the doctor find a cause? for Non.

Why can't the doctor find a cause?

 MRI doesn't show everything - and shows too much

 An important study by Brinjikji and colleagues (AJNR 2015) examined MRI scans of people with no back pain at all. The findings were striking
 MRI Finding 
 20-year-olds without pain 
 80-year-olds without pain 

 Disc degeneration 
 37% 
 96% 

 Disc bulging 
 30% 
 84% 

 This means that much of what MRI shows is normal age-related change . Degeneration in 37% of 20-year-olds without pain (Brinjikji et al., AJNR 2015) and disc bulging from 30% at age 20 to 84% at age 80 - all without symptoms (Brinjikji et al., AJNR 2015). Wear, bulging and degeneration are just as common in healthy backs as in painful ones.

 This is why all international guidelines recommend against routine MRI for lower back pain without red flags (WHO 2023). Unnecessary imaging can actually make things worse: terms like "wear and tear", "degeneration" and "herniation" can create fear and avoidance behaviour - even when the findings are completely normal for the person's age.

 When is MRI appropriate?

 Imaging is considered when red flags are present, with progressive neurological deficits, or when there is no improvement after 6-12 weeks of adequate treatment. Clinical examination is usually sufficient to start treatment.

 Pain is more than tissue damage

 Modern research has shown that pain is a complex phenomenon influenced by far more than tissue damage alone. The biopsychosocial model views pain as an interplay between three domains
 Biological factors

 Muscle tension, joint stiffness, deconditioning, inflammation and sleep deprivation. These factors are real and treatable.

 Psychological factors

 Thoughts and emotions affect the pain experience. Fear of movement (kinesiophobia), catastrophic thinking and low self-efficacy can amplify and perpetuate pain. This is not about the pain being psychological - but about the brain regulating the pain experience.

What causes T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms?

Causes and Risk Factors

 

 Since T4 syndrome is poorly defined in research, we don't have reliable data on causation. The leading
 theory involves the sympathetic nervous system:

 Sympathetic Nerve Theory (Theoretical)

 Sympathetic nerve fibers supplying the upper extremities originate from spinal cord levels T2-T5. The
 sympathetic ganglia are located directly in front of the costovertebral joints. The theory is that
 stiffness or dysfunction in these joints can irritate sympathetic structures and cause referred symptoms
 to the hands (Evans, 1997; Maitland, 1986).

 Risk Factors Based on Case Reports

 From available case descriptions, we see some patterns:

 
 Prolonged sitting and office work

 Forward head posture ("computer neck"), which can also contribute to kyphosis

 Women are affected more often than men - case reports suggest a ratio of 3:1 to 4:1
 (DeFranca & Levine, 1995)

 The 30-50 age group is most represented in the literature

 

 It must be emphasized that these figures come from individual case reports with very few patients,
 not from epidemiological studies.

Beskriv Ensidig vs. tosidig - hva er forskjellen? for Vestibulær Hypofunksjon: Den Komplette Guiden.

Ensidig vs. tosidig - hva er forskjellen?

 

 Vestibulær hypofunksjon deles inn i to hovedtyper, og forskjellene er betydelige - både når det gjelder symptomer, Årsaker og prognose.

 
 Unilateral vestibulær hypofunksjon (ensidig)

 Ved ensidig hypofunksjon er balanseorganet skadet på kun en side. Dette er den vanligste formen og skyldes oftest vestibularisnevritt (virus på balansenerven).

 Hvordan fungerer det? Balanseorganene i høyre og venstre Øre fungerer normalt som et "push-pull"-system. Når du snur hodet til høyre, Økersignalet fra høyre Øre mens det minker fra venstre. Ved ensidig skade oppstar en ubalanse som hjernen tolker som konstant rotasjon. Den gode nyheten er at hjernen er bemerkelsesverdig flink til å kompensere for ensidig skade.

 

 
 Bilateral vestibulær hypofunksjon (tosidig)

 Ved tosidig hypofunksjon fungerer balanseorganene dårlig eller ikke i det hele tatt på begge sider. Dette er en sjeldnere og mer alvorlig tilstand.

 Hvordan fungerer det? Når begge sider er "tause", får hjernen ingen informasjon om hodets bevegelser. Det er som å kjore bil uten speedometer og uten vinduer - du aner ikke hvordan du beveger deg.

 Forekomst: Ca. 28 per 100 000 voksne. Gjennomsnittsalderen ved diagnose er 58-64 Ør, og menn rammes noe oftere enn kvinner.

Describe The Tennis Player: The Serve That Reveals the Stiffness for How a Stiff Back Ruins Your Golf Swing and Tennis Serve.

The Tennis Player: The Serve That Reveals the Stiffness

 

 The tennis serve is one of the most demanding movements in sports. Kibler and colleagues established as
 early as 1995 that legs, hips, and trunk together contribute approximately 51% of kinetic energy
 and 54% of total force in a serve. The rest comes from shoulder, arm, and wrist.

 A stiff thoracic spine limits how much energy can be generated and transferred through this chain. The
 shoulder must then compensate with higher velocity to achieve the same result - and this increases load
 and injury risk.

 
 The Good News from Research

 A study published in Frontiers in Sports and Active Living (Le Solliec et al., 2023) followed 22
 competitive tennis players through an 8-week program of stretching, strength, and mobilization
 exercises:

 
 The percentage of successful serves increased from 41% to 55%

 Serve velocity and accuracy improved significantly (effect size 0.54-0.65)

 Shoulder mobility increased markedly, especially external rotation (effect size 1.49)

 
 The program focused on thoracic and shoulder mobility combined with strength exercises - four
 sessions per week for eight weeks. And this was without any form of manual treatment.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Horizontal Canal BPPV.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Why is horizontal canal BPPV worse than posterior canal?

 Many patients experience the symptoms as more intense. This may be due to the horizontal canal's larger diameter and stronger response to head movements.

 

 
 Can I do exercises at home?

 Some home exercises can be useful as a supplement, but initial diagnosis and treatment should be performed by qualified healthcare professionals. It is important to know which variant you have.

 

 
 Is horizontal canal BPPV dangerous?

 The condition itself is not dangerous, but the intense dizziness significantly increases fall risk. It is important to get a correct diagnosis to rule out other causes.

Describe symptoms for SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 Symptoms of SLAP lesion can be vague and overlap with many other shoulder conditions
 Common symptoms

 Deep pain: Often difficult to localize, "inside" the shoulder

 Pain during overhead activity: Especially when throwing or hitting above the head

 Clicking or snapping: Mechanical symptoms during movement (see clicking in the shoulder )

 Pain in "late cocking" position: Arm back and up, ready to throw

 Feeling of instability: Shoulder feels "loose" or "gives way"

 Reduced throwing velocity/distance: In athletes

 Symptoms that may point to SLAP

 Pain at the end of the throwing motion

 Clicking at specific shoulder positions

 Pain during biceps loading combined with overhead pain

 Feeling of "dead arm" after throwing

 Diagnostic challenge

 SLAP lesions are notoriously difficult to diagnose clinically. Symptoms overlap with many conditions
 (impingement, rotator cuff problems, biceps tendinopathy), and no single test is sufficiently
 reliable. Shoulder pain can also be worsened by poor ergonomics .

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Nummenhet i fingrene - Nakke eller hand?.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kommer nummenheten fra nakken eller handen?

 Det avhenger av hvilke fingre som er påvirket og ledsagende symptomer. Tommel, pekefinger og langfinger er typisk for karpaltunnel, mens lillefinger og ringfinger ofte peker mot nakke eller albue. Nakkesmerter og utstraling i armen tyder på nakkeÅrsak.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen mellom karpaltunnelsyndrom og cervikal radikulopati?

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom skyldes klem på medianusnerven i handleddet og gir nummenhet i tommel, pekefinger og langfinger. Cervikal radikulopati skyldes nerverotpåvirkning i nakken og gir ofte utstraling fra nakke ned i armen, samt nummenhet i et dermatom-mønster.

 

 
 Hvorfor blir fingrene numne om natten?

 Ved karpaltunnel er nummenhet om natten typisk fordi vi ofte sover med bøyde handledd, noe som Øker trykket i karpaltunnelen. å bruke en nattskinne som holder handleddet rett kan hjelpe betydelig.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor behandle nummenhet i fingrene?

 Ja, kiropraktorer kan undersøke og behandle både nakke- og handrelaterte Årsaker til nummenhet. Behandlingen retter seg mot den underliggende Årsaken, enten det er nakkeproblem, karpaltunnel eller annen nervepåvirkning.

 

 
 Når trenger jeg operasjon for nummenhet i fingrene?

 Operasjon vurderes vanligvis først når konservativ behandling ikke har hjulpet over flere måneder, eller ved alvorlige tilfeller med betydelig svakhet eller muskeltap. En nerveledestudie (EMG) kan hjelpe med å vurdere alvorlighetsgraden.

Hvordan diagnostiseres Nakkeprolaps og Nerve i Klem i Nakken?

Diagnostikk

 

 Kliniske tester

 En grundig klinisk undersøkelse er ofte viktigere enn bilder. Kiropraktoren vurderer nakkebevegelighet, muskelkraft, fålsomhet og reflekser.

 
 Spurlings test

 Nakken ekstenderes, sideflekteres og roteres mot symptomsiden, deretter påføres trykk. Høy spesifisitet på 92%, men sensitivitet på bare 53%. En positiv test styrker mistanken betydelig, men negativ test utelukker ikke tilstanden.

 

 
 Upper Limb Tension Test (ULTT)

 97% sensitivitet - en negativ test gjør diagnosen usannsynlig. Mange falske positive (22% spesifisitet).

 

 
 Arm Squeeze Test

 96,7% sensitivitet for å skille nakkeproblemer fra skulderproblemer. Klem på midten av overarmen gir smerte ved nakkepatologi, men ikke ved ren skulderpatologi.

 

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR er ikke rutine og bør forbeholdes: vedvarende symptomer etter 4-6 uker konservativ behandling, progredierende nevrologisk svikt, mistanke om alvorlig underliggende sykdom, eller får eventuell kirurgisk vurdering.

 
 MR-funn hos symptomfrie personer (Brinjikji, AJNR 2015)

 Ved 30 Ør: 52% har diskedegenerasjon, 40% skivebukning
 Ved 50 Ør: 80% har diskedegenerasjon, 60% skivebukning
 Ved 70 Ør: 93% har diskedegenerasjon, 77% skivebukning

Identify red flags for Scoliosis – Curved Spine in Children and Adults.

Red Flags – When to Seek Help Immediately

 Emergency (call emergency services)

 Changes in bladder or bowel function

 Rapidly progressive weakness or numbness in the legs

 New-onset scoliosis with acute neurological symptoms

 Within 24–48 hours

 Rapid worsening of the curve (over 5 degrees in 6 months)

 Pain combined with weakness or numbness in the legs

 Breathing difficulties related to the curve

 Planned Evaluation

 Persistent back pain in children or adolescents (unusual in idiopathic scoliosis – should be investigated for other causes)

 Left-sided thoracic curve (atypical pattern that may indicate an underlying cause)

 Scoliosis discovered late in the growth period with a large curve

 Painful scoliosis in adults with neurological symptoms

 Important for Parents

 Back pain in children and adolescents with scoliosis is unusual and should be investigated for other causes. Idiopathic scoliosis itself is rarely painful at a young age.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Do You Need an MRI for Back Pain?.

"Can I get an MRI?": This is a question I hear often at the clinic. Many believe an MRI will give them the answer to why their back hurts. The thinking is understandable: modern technology should be able to show what's wrong, right?

MRI Findings Are Common in Healthy People: Here comes perhaps the most important insight: most of what I see on MRI is completely normal - even if it sounds scary.

Why Can MRI Actually Make Things Worse?: When you're told you have "herniation," "degeneration," or "wear" in your back, something happens in your mind. Words have power. In medicine, this is called the nocebo effect - negative expectations actually worsen the experience and outcome.

What Do the Guidelines Say?: All major international professional bodies agree: routine imaging for non-specific back pain is not recommended.

When IS Imaging Necessary?: All of the above does not mean MRI is never useful. There are clear situations where prompt investigation is essential.

Clinical Examination Is Often More Important Than Images: A thorough clinical examination can provide a lot of information. By testing movement, strength, reflexes, and sensation, an experienced practitioner can often
What Can You Do Instead of Getting an MRI?: For the vast majority with back pain - over 90% - the cause is non-specific. This means there is no dangerous or specific disease, but rather muscle and joint-related problems that respond well to
Frequently Asked Questions: For most people with back pain, MRI will show "findings" that don't explain your pain - because these findings are equally common in healthy people. A clinical examination often provides more useful information.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan kostokondritt våre farlig?

 Nei, kostokondritt er en godartet tilstand som ikke skader hjertet eller andre organer. Utfordringen er at symptomene kan ligne hjertesykdom, så det er viktig å få utelukket alvorlige Årsaker først.

 

 
 Hvordan skiller man kostokondritt fra hjerteinfarkt?

 Kostokondritt gir typisk skarp, lokalisert smerte som forverres ved bevegelse og pust, og som kan gjenskapes ved trykk. Hjerteinfarkt gir ofte trykkende, diffuse smerter med utstråling, ledsaget av svette, kvalme og pustevansker. Ved tvil - ring 113.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor behandle kostokondritt?

 Ja, kiropraktor kan vurdere og behandle kostokondritt. Behandlingen fokuserer på å gjenopprette normal bevegelighet i brystrygg og ribbein. Studier viser lovende resultater, selv om evidensgrunnlaget er begrenset.

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det får kostokondritt går over?

 De fleste opplever betydelig bedring innen 3-4 uker med riktig behandling. Noen tilfeller kan vare opptil 1-2 måneder, og enkelte kan ha milde symptomer i opptil et Ør.

 

 
 Trenger jeg røntgen eller MR?

 Vanligvis ikke. Kostokondritt diagnostiseres klinisk. Bildediagnostikk brukes primært for å utelukke andre tilstander ved atypiske symptomer eller manglende behandlingsrespons.

 

 
 Kan kostokondritt komme tilbake?

 Tilbakefallsraten er relativt lav (ca. 4% over to Ør). God holdning, unngåelse av overbelastning, og vedlikehold av bevegelighet i brystryggen kan redusere risikoen.

How is Bra Strap Syndrome and Shoulder Pain diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Diagnosis is made primarily through clinical examination. The medical history is often revealing: pain
 that varies with bra use, visible strap grooves, and improvement on weekends or vacations when the patient
 wears a bra less.

 Differential Diagnoses to Consider

 
 
 
 Condition
 Characteristics
 Distinguished by
 
 
 
 
 Cervical Radiculopathy
 Typically one-sided, follows dermatome
 Positive Spurling's test, reflex changes
 
 
 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome / T4 Syndrome
 Similar symptoms, often one-sided
 No visible strap grooves, vascular symptoms
 
 
 Rotator Cuff Problems
 Painful arc, weakness in certain movements
 Positive impingement tests, pain with active movements
 
 
 

 
 About Imaging

 MRI and X-rays are rarely necessary for bra strap syndrome. These examinations often show "normal
 findings" like degenerative changes that don't explain the pain. Clinical examination - focusing on
 strap grooves, symptom patterns and response to bra removal - is more important than images.

Beskriv Ofte Stilte Spørsmål for Akutt Ryggsmerte: Hva Du Bør Gjøre de Første Timene og Dagene.

Ofte Stilte Spørsmål

 

 
 Bør jeg ta røntgen eller MR med en gang?

 Nei, som regel ikke. Bildediagnostikk er sjelden nødvendig ved akutt ryggsmerte uten røde flagg - selv ved mistanke om prolaps. De fleste bedres uansett innen 6 uker. MR kan være aktuelt hvis smertene ikke bedres eller ved nevrologiske symptomer.

 

 
 Hvor lenge bør jeg være sykemeldt?

 Kortest mulig! Forskning viser at tidlig tilbakegang til (tilpasset) arbeid gir bedre prognose enn langvarig sykemelding. Diskuter med behandler om gradert sykemelding eller tilrettelegging.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med akutt ryggsmerte?

 Lett aktivitet som gåing er bra. Intens trening bør utsettes til akuttfasen er over (typisk 1-2 uker). Tung styrketrening og aktiviteter med mye vridning/bøying bør vente til smertene er under kontroll.

 

 
 Er det bedre med hard eller myk madrass?

 Moderat fast madrass er ofte best. For hard gir trykk, for myk gir dårlig støtte. Viktigst er at du finner en stilling der du kan sove - søvn er viktig for tilheling!

 

 
 Hjelper kiropraktor ved akutt ryggsmerte?

 Ja. Kiropraktorer har god erfaring med akutte ryggepisoder og bruker tilpassede teknikker i akuttfasen. Ofte kan tidlig behandling forkorte sykdomsforløpet og gi deg konkrete strategier for raskere bedring.

Patient asks: "What is the difference between frozen shoulder and shoulder osteoarthritis?"

Frozen shoulder is stiffness in the joint capsule and often resolves on its own. Shoulder osteoarthritis is wear in the cartilage itself. Frozen shoulder causes more pronounced movement restriction and is not age-related in the same way as osteoarthritis.

Hvor lang tid tar det for øvelser virker?

 Forvent ikke mirakler over natten. Tidlig respons kan merkes etter 1-2 uker, men meningsfull bedring krever typisk 6-8 uker med konsekvent innsats (PMC, 2023).

 Typisk forløp

 Uke 1-2: Noen merker lett lindring, andre ingen endring enna

 Uke 4-6: Gradvis bedring i smerte og bevegelighet

 Uke 8-12: Betydelig funksjonsforbedring hos de fleste

 3-6 måneder: Vedlikeholdsfase - kan redusere treningsfrekvens

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Triggerpunkter utvikles når muskelfibre blir overbelastet eller skadet. De vanligste årsakene:

 
 Statisk belastning og dårlig ergonomi

You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
What is the prognosis for Headache After Whiplash - Post-Traumatic Headache?

Prognosis - What happens?

 

 The first 3 months are crucial

 Research shows that improvement mainly occurs during the first 3 months after the injury. After this,
 the improvement curve flattens dramatically. A study found that 86% of those who were still symptomatic
 at 3 months remained symptomatic after 2 years.

 Three typical courses (Sterling et al., JOSPT 2016)

 
 
 ~50%
 Mild course: Full recovery
 

 
 ~30%
 Moderate course: Persistent moderate symptoms
 

 
 ~20%
 Severe course: Chronic disability
 

 

 Risk factors for poor outcome

 High initial pain intensity, high functional disability from the start, cold sensitivity, pain
 catastrophizing and post-traumatic stress symptoms increase the risk of chronicity. Low expectations of
 improvement is a strong negative prognostic factor.

 Relapse is common

 Even among those who recover, many experience relapse. Long-term studies show that only about 35% are
 fully recovered after 5 years. This underscores the importance of learning self-management strategies.

Provide a structured clinical overview of You Don't Have to Live With Dizziness Anymore.

Three Myths You Often Hear: Research from Imperial College London has established that dizziness is not a normal part of aging. Yes, incidence increases - studies show that up to 31% of people over 80 experience dizziness, but this is due to treatable conditions, not aging itself. The most common causes in the elderly are BPPV and medication side effects, both with good treatment options.

The Most Common Causes of Dizziness: BPPV (benign paroxysmal positional vertigo) is the most common cause of rotational dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. The condition occurs when small calcium particles dislodge in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

What Can I Offer?: At TheBackROM at Majorstua, I specialize in evaluation and treatment of dizziness. I have invested in equipment that makes it possible to diagnose and treat even those who have had challenges elsewhere
What Can You Expect?: I start with a thorough review of your medical history and symptoms. Then I do a systematic examination including testing of balance, eye movements, and neck. If BPPV is suspected, I perform diagnostic tests like Dix-Hallpike. Based on findings, I discuss a plan together with you.

Are You Ready to Get Help?: . I offer thorough evaluation with VNG and TRV chair.

Du er en rask klinisk tekstassistent. Generer korte, presise kliniske oppsummeringer for kiropraktisk dokumentasjon.
Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Menieres Sykdom.

Hvor vanlig er Menieres sykdom?: Menieres sykdom er relativt sjelden. Forekomsten varierer mellom studier, men estimater ligger på 50-200 per 100.000 voksne. Sykdommen rammer oftest personer mellom 40 og 60 år, med en topp i 40- og 50-Ørene. Kvinner rammes noe hyppigere enn menn, med et forhold på omtrent 1,5-1,9:1. Mindre enn 3% av tilfellene oppstår hos personer under 18 år.

Hva skjer i året?: Den underliggende mekanismen antas å vare endolymfatisk hydrops - en opphopning av vaeske (endolymfe) i det indre øret. Det indre øret bestar av et labyrintsystem fylt med vaeske som må ha riktig trykk og kjemisk sammensetning for å fungere normalt.

Symptomer: I tillegg opplever mange trykkfølelse eller "fylde" i det affiserte øret, aura for anfall (endret øresus, økende trykk), og ekstrem utmattelse etter anfall.

Diagnostikk: Det finnes ingen enkelt test som kan bekrefte Menieres sykdom. Diagnosen stilles klinisk basert på internasjonale kriterier (Barany Society/AAO-HNS, 2015/2020). Det er viktig å skille Menieres fra andre tilstander som vestibular migrene , vestibularisnevritt og krystallsyke (BPPV) .

Behandling: Det finnes ingen kur for Menieres sykdom. Målet med behandlingen er å redusere anfallshyppighet, lindre symptomer og bedre livskvaliteten.

Prognose: I noen tilfeller kan den kroniske svimmelheten utvikle seg til PPPD (vedvarende postural-perseptuell svimmelhet) , som krever en egen behandlingstilnærming.
Foreslå hjemmeøvelser for rotator cuff tendinopati.

Hjemmeøvelsesprogram - Rotator Cuff Tendinopati

Fase 1: Smertelindring (Uke 1-2)
1. Pendel-øvelser: Len fremover, la armen henge, sirkler 30 sek hver retning x3
2. Isometrisk UR: Albue 90°, trykk ut mot dørpost, hold 10 sek x10
3. Isometrisk IR: Albue 90°, trykk inn mot dørpost, hold 10 sek x10
4. Scapula-retraksjoner: Klem skulderbladene sammen, hold 5 sek x15

Fase 2: Styrke (Uke 3-6)
5. UR med strikk: Albue inntil kropp, 90° bøy, roter ut. 3x15
6. IR med strikk: Samme posisjon, roter inn. 3x15
7. Wallslides: Rygg mot vegg, gli armer opp. 3x12
8. Full can: Tommel opp, løft arm til 90° i skapulærplanet. 3x12 med lett vekt

Fase 3: Funksjon (Uke 7+)
9. Around the world med strikk: 3x10
10. Push-up mot vegg → benk → gulv progresjon
11. Roing med strikk: 3x15

Dosering: Daglig. Smerte akseptabelt opp til 3-4/10 under trening, skal roe seg innen 24 timer. Stopp ved skarp smerte.

Løpetrening med løperkne

 

 Mange lurer på om de må slutte å løpe. Svaret er som regel nei - men du må justere:

 Kan jeg fortsette å løpe?

 Ja, ofte - men med modifikasjoner. NØkkelprinsippet er å finne den "dosen" med løping kneet tolererer, og bygge derfra.

 Praktiske tips

 
 Reduser distanse: Start på 50-70% av det som gir smerte

Describe What is the SI Joint? for SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

What is the SI Joint?

 

 The SI joint is a unique joint - part synovial joint (movable), part fibrous joint (stable). Normal
 movement is very limited: only 2-4 mm rotation and 1-2 mm gliding. Nevertheless, these minimal movements
 are essential for normal walking function and for absorbing shock.

 
 Why does the SI joint cause pain in the back, buttocks and thigh?

 The SI joint receives sensory innervation from both anterior (L2-S2) and posterior (L4-S3) nerve roots.
 This complex innervation explains why SI joint pain can produce varying referral patterns - from lower
 back to buttocks, groin, thigh and sometimes down toward the foot.

 

 How common is SI joint pain?

 International consensus guidelines from 2025, developed in collaboration between 27 organizations,
 establish that the SI joint is the cause of 15-30% of chronic lower back pain without
 radiation down the leg (Pain Medicine, 2025). A systematic review by Simopoulos et al. found point
 prevalence of approximately 25%.

 
 
 15-30%
 of chronic lower back pain
 

 
 60-65%
 of patients are women
 

 
 2-4 mm
 normal joint mobility

DETTE ER VIKTIG

 Smerten din er reell. Nociplastisk smerte er ikke innbilt, psykosomatisk eller "bare i hodet."

 Behandling tar tid. Dette er en gradvis prosess, ikke en rask fix.

Describe Myofascial trigger points in the context of Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck.

Myofascial trigger points

 Active trigger points in the upper trapezius occur in 30-40% of patients with chronic neck pain. Causes radiation that can mimic radiculopathy.

 

 Risk factors

 
 Age over 50

 Heavy physical work with lifting over 25 kg

 Work with vibrating equipment

 Prolonged driving

 Smoking (affects blood supply to discs)

 Sedentary work with poor ergonomics

 Previous back pain (41% have had lumbar radiculopathy)

 
 

 
 
 3
 Which nerves are affected - and what characterizes each?

 

 The neck has seven cervical vertebrae, and the nerves exiting between them are named after the vertebra
 above. Note: Only 62.6% of patients have standard dermatome patterns, and 67.3% show typical myotome
 patterns (Neurospine 2022). About one-third have atypical symptoms.

 
 C7 radiculopathy (most common - 60-70% of cases)

 
 Disc level: C6-C7

 Sensory: Tingling, numbness in the middle
 finger (finger 3). May also be felt on the back of the forearm.

 Muscle weakness: Triceps (elbow extension), wrist flexors and finger extensors.
 

 Reflex change: Reduced triceps reflex.

How is Snapping Hip - When Your Hip Clicks and Pops diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 Clinical Examination is Key

 In most cases, the diagnosis is clinical - meaning the examination provides the answer without the need
 for imaging. The most reliable test is reproducing the snap during examination.

 When is Imaging Needed?

 
 When the snap cannot be reproduced

 When labral tear is suspected

 When there is no improvement after 2-3 months

 With red flags

 When surgery is being considered

 
 
 Imaging Modalities

 Dynamic ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for snapping hip outside the
 joint. MR arthrography is the gold standard when labral tear is suspected, with
 approximately 90% sensitivity.

Differential diagnoses for Numbness in Fingers: Is It the Neck or the Hand??

Carpal tunnel syndrome - the wrist

 The carpal tunnel is a narrow passage in the wrist where the median nerve passes through. When space becomes too tight, typically due to swelling in tendons or surrounding tissue, the nerve doesn't have enough room.

 Affects 1-5% of the population. Women are affected 3-4 times more often than men, most commonly between ages 40-60.

Cervical radiculopathy - the neck

 With cervical radiculopathy, a nerve root in the neck is pinched or irritated, usually due to degenerative changes (70-75%) or disc herniation (20-25%).

Describe treatment options for Hallux Valgus (Bunion).

Evidence-Based Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment is the first choice and is effective for most people. The goal is pain relief,
 slowing progression, and maintaining function.

 
 Gold Standard: Conservative Treatment First

 80-90% of patients with hallux valgus achieve satisfactory pain relief with conservative measures.
 Surgery is reserved for cases with significant pain and functional impairment after failed conservative
 treatment.

 

 Conservative Measures

 
 
 1

 
 Proper Footwear

 Shoes with wide toe box and low heel. Avoid pointed shoes and heels over 2-3 cm. This is the most
 important single measure.

 

 

 
 2

 
 Toe Spreaders

 Provide pain relief and better toe separation during use. Start gradually with short periods. Does
 not permanently change the deformity but can slow progression.

 

 

 
 3

 
 Strengthening Exercises for Foot Muscles

 Strengthening of abductor hallucis and intrinsic foot muscles. "Toe yoga", towel gathering with
 toes, and foot arch activation.

 

 

 
 4

 
 Manual Treatment

 Joint mobilization of the MTP joint and midfoot. Soft tissue techniques for tight muscles. Can
 improve mobility and reduce pain.

 

 

 
 5

 
 Protective Padding
 Gel padding over the protruding joint to reduce friction and pain in shoes.

 

 

 

 Exercises for Hallux Valgus

 Regular exercises can strengthen the supporting muscles and potentially slow progression:

 
 Big toe abduction: Spread the big toe away from the other toes, hold 5 secon...

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Achilles Tendinopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise with Achilles tendinopathy?

 Yes, in most cases. Silbernagel's pain monitoring model (2007) shows that
 continued activity is safe as long as pain stays below 5/10 during exercise and doesn't worsen the next
 day. You may need to adjust type, duration or intensity temporarily.

 

 
 Is there inflammation in my tendon?

 No, despite many calling it "tendinitis". Modern research shows that Achilles
 tendinopathy is primarily a degenerative process with changes in tendon structure, not classic
 inflammation. This is also why anti-inflammatory medications have limited effect.

 

 
 Do I need an MRI or ultrasound?

 Rarely. The diagnosis is made clinically, and imaging usually doesn't change the
 treatment plan. Important to know: 46% of symptom-free runners have tendon changes on ultrasound.
 Imaging is primarily done when rupture is suspected, for uncertain diagnoses, or for surgical
 evaluation.

 

 
 Do heel lifts or orthotic insoles help?

 The evidence is limited. Heel lifts can provide temporary pain relief by reducing
 the stretch on the tendon, but should be viewed as a supplement to - not a replacement for -
 exercise-based treatment.

 

 
 How long until I recover?

 It depends on duration and severity. Acute cases (< 6 weeks) can improve in 6-12
 weeks, while chronic cases often require 3-6 months - sometimes up to a year. The key is patience and
 consistent completion of the exercise program.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Dizziness - Causes, Symptoms and Effective Treatment.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the most common cause of dizziness?

 BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) is the most common cause and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. It has a success rate of 80-90% with the Epley maneuver.

 

 
 Can neck problems cause dizziness?

 Yes, neck-related (cervicogenic) dizziness is common but often misdiagnosed. The neck contains sensors that tell the brain about the head's position, and problems here can cause unsteadiness and a swaying feeling.

 

 
 Is dizziness just part of getting older?

 No, that's a myth. Most forms of dizziness can be treated effectively regardless of age. Adapted movement and balance training is crucial for recovery.

Clinical summary of Vestibular Neuritis.

Key Summary

 What it is: Acute inflammation of the balance nerve (vestibular nerve) on one side

 Most common cause: Reactivation of herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) in the nerve ganglion

 Treatment: Vestibular rehabilitation has strong evidence (Cochrane 2015)

 Prognosis: 50-70% achieve full or near-full recovery

 Red flags: Double vision, speech difficulties, swallowing problems, severe headache, hearing loss - call 113

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Costochondritis and Chest Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can costochondritis be dangerous?

 No, costochondritis is a benign condition that does not harm the heart or other
 organs. The challenge is that the symptoms can resemble heart disease, so it's important to rule out
 serious causes first.

 

 
 How do you distinguish costochondritis from a heart attack?

 Costochondritis typically causes sharp, localized pain that worsens with movement
 and breathing, and can be reproduced by pressing on the area. Heart attack often causes pressing,
 diffuse pain with radiation, accompanied by sweating, nausea and difficulty breathing. When in doubt -
 call emergency services.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor treat costochondritis?

 Yes, a chiropractor can assess and treat costochondritis. Treatment focuses on
 restoring normal mobility in the thoracic spine and ribs. Studies show promising results, although the
 evidence base is limited.

 

 
 How long does it take for costochondritis to resolve?

 Most people experience significant improvement within 3-4 weeks with proper
 treatment. Some cases can last up to 1-2 months, and some may have mild symptoms for up to a year.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 Usually not. Costochondritis is diagnosed clinically. Imaging is primarily used to
 rule out other conditions with atypical symptoms or lack of treatment response.

 

 
 Can costochondritis come back?

 The recurrence rate is relatively low (about 4% over two years). Good posture,
 avoiding overexertion, and ...

Describe What Can the Chiropractor Do? for Breathing, Stress and Back.

What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 

 Thoracic Mobilization

 Treatment of stiffness in the thoracic spine and rib joints can help restore normal movement. This
 includes mobilization of the costovertebral joints (where the ribs meet the vertebrae) and general
 thoracic mobilization. Read more about thoracic pain and treatment
 options.

 
 Note

 The evidence that spinal treatment directly affects autonomic functions is limited (as discussed
 above). But many patients experience that better mobility in the thoracic spine makes it easier to
 breathe deeply and relaxed.

 

 Posture Guidance

 An important part of treatment is awareness about work position, phone use, and everyday habits. Simple
 adjustments can have a big effect over time.

 Breathing Training as Part of Treatment

 Chiropractors with competence in breathing function can guide in diaphragmatic breathing and integrate
 this into the treatment course. In Norway, there is a tradition of interdisciplinary collaboration -
 psychomotor physiotherapy (NPMP) has combined breathing, posture, and stress treatment for over 50 years.

Skriv notat om hjernerystelse og BPPV

KLINISK NOTAT - HJERNERYSTELSE OG BPPV

Dato: [Dato]
Pasient: [Navn]

Pasienten er undersøkt for vedvarende svimmelhet, hodepine og ustøhet etter [hendelse], hvor [hun/han] pådro seg en hjernerystelse etter et slag mot [side] side av hodet.

Symptomer:
Pasienten beskriver bevegelsesutløst svimmelhet, generell ustøhet ved gange og vansker med å fokusere blikket. [Hun/Han] opplever hodepine som et "belte over pannen", samt smerter i kjeve, nakke og skulder.

Kliniske funn og vurdering:
Undersøkelsen avdekker funn som tyder på en kombinasjon av en perifer og en sentral årsak til symptomene:

Perifer vestibulopati (BPPV):
Supine Roll Test var positiv med en kraftig [retning]-rettet horisontal nystagmus, noe som bekrefter diagnosen BPPV i [side] horisontale buegang.

Sentralvestibulær påvirkning (etter hjernerystelse):
VNG-testing og klinisk undersøkelse viste flere tegn på sentral påvirkning:
- Sakkader og pursuits: Begge testene viste "overshoots" og korrigerende sakkader
- Blikkhold (Gaze) og Headshake-test: Provoserte nystagmus

Disse funnene er forenlige med en post-commotio tilstand.

Konklusjon og plan:
Pasienten har en BPPV i den horisontale buegangen, i tillegg til en sentralvestibulær dysfunksjon som følge av hjernerystelsen.

Det er satt i gang følgende tiltak:
1. Behandling for BPPV: Reposisjoneringsmanøver tilpasset horisontal buegang
2. Vestibulær rehabilitering (VRT): Pasienten starter med lette VRT-øvelser for gaze stability. Dette er første steg i en progressiv oppfølging.

Målet er å gradvis forbedre sentralvestibulær funksjon, noe som vil bli monitorert ved fremtidig VNG-retesting.

Pasienten vil bli fulgt opp for videre behandling og justering av øvelser.

Beskriv hvordan stilles diagnosen? for Kasterskulder og GIRD: Når kasting gir skuldersmerter.

Hvordan stilles diagnosen?

 Diagnosen stilles primært gjennom klinisk undersøkelse med fokus på bevegelsesmaling og provokasjonstester.

 Bevegelsesvurdering

 Maling av rotasjon

 Begge skuldre males i 90 graders abduksjon
 Innadrotasjon (IR): Normalt ca. 70-90

 Utadrotasjon (ER): Normalt ca. 90-110

 Totalt ROM: IR + ER bør være tilnærmet likt på begge sider

 GIRD-kriterier

 Asymptomatisk GIRD: Redusert IR på dominansiden, men totalt ROM er bevart (Økt ER kompenserer).

 Symptomatisk GIRD: Redusert totalt ROM (>5) sammenlignet med motsatt side, eller smerter ved testing.

 Kliniske tester

 Posteriort impingement-test

 Armen føres i maksimal utadrotasjon og abduksjon. Smerte bak i skulderen indikerer intern impingement.

 Sleeper stretch-stilling

 Test innadrotasjon med pasienten liggende på siden. Sammenlign med motsatt side.

 SLAP-tester 

 O'Brien's test, anterior slide, biceps load II for å vurdere labrum-patologi.

 Bildediagnostikk

 Bildediagnostikk er sjelden nødvendig for å diagnostisere GIRD, men kan være aktuelt ved
 Mistanke om strukturell skade (SLAP, rotatorcuff-rift)

 Manglende respons på konservativ behandling

 Akutt skade eller trauma

 MR-artrografi er best for å vurdere labrum og rotatorcuff hos kasteutovere.

Assess red flags: 40-year-old female with pain in both buttock regions and back of both thighs. Worse with prolonged sitting. Tender piriformis bilaterally. Normal SLR. Normal perineal sensation. Normal urination.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral buttock pain is NOT CES:
- Bilateral buttock pain is common with piriformis/gluteal dysfunction, especially with prolonged sitting
- Pain stops at THIGH, not down to foot (CES typically causes bilateral sciatica TO FOOT)
- Normal SLR bilaterally = no nerve root irritation
- CRITICAL: Normal perineal sensation and normal urination rules out CES
- Saddle anesthesia = numbness in groin/anus, NOT in gluteal muscles
- Bilateral piriformis syndrome is common with sedentary work

Clinical picture: Bilateral piriformis syndrome / deep gluteal pain.

Safe to treat with piriformis stretching, gluteal strengthening, sitting ergonomics.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Popliteus syndrom.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Popliteus syndrom oppstår vanligvis gradvis som følge av overbelastning
 Nedoverbakker

 Vanligste årsak 

 Ved nedoverbakkeløping må popliteus jobbe hardt for å kontrollere knefleksjon og hindre at kneet hyperekstenderer. Terrengløping og fjelltur er typiske triggere.

 Overbelastning

 For rask økning i treningsmengde, intensitet eller endring i underlag kan overbelaste popliteus for den rekker å tilpasse seg.

 Biomekaniske faktorer

 Overpronasjon (fotfeil)

 Svak hoftemuskulatur

 Stramme hamstrings eller legger

 Dårlig knekontroll

 Ytre faktorer

 Loping på skrått underlag (alltid samme retning)

 Slitte løpesko

 Hardt underlag

 Akutte årsaker

 I noen tilfeller kan popliteus skades akutt ved
 Direkte traume mot kneet

 Kraftig vridning

 Hyperekstensjon av kneet

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Differential diagnoses for Pain Between Shoulder Blades?

Myofascial pain with trigger points

 Myofascial pain with trigger points in the musculature is by far the most common cause of acute pain
 between the shoulder blades. A study in Pain Medicine (2016) found that 93% of patients with chronic
 neck pain had trigger points in the trapezius.

 The muscles between the shoulder blades - especially the rhomboids and middle trapezius - often become
 overloaded from prolonged sitting with forward-leaning posture.

Cervicogenic pain

 French orthopedist Robert Maigne described how up to 70% of "common" pain between the shoulder blades
 actually originates from the lower neck (C5-C7). The facet joints in the neck can refer pain to the area
 along the medial border of the shoulder blade.

 This explains why many experience improvement in shoulder blade pain when the neck is treated.

Facet joint problems

 Facet joints in the chest contribute to 34-48% of chronic chest pain according to studies with
 diagnostic blocks (Manchikanti, Pain Physician, 2004; 2020). These small joints between the vertebrae
 can become irritated or worn, especially with repetitive movements or prolonged poor posture. In more
 severe cases, it may involve thoracic disc herniation .

 Dreyfuss and colleagues (Spine, 1994) mapped how these joints typically produce pain one segment down
 and slightly to the side.

Upper crossed syndrome

 Vladimir Janda described in the 1980s what he called "upper crossed syndrome": an imbalance where
 anterior muscles (chest, neck) become tight while posterior muscles (rhomboids, middle trapezius) become
 weak and stretched. This pattern can be reinforced by rounded back
 (hyperkyphosis) or conversely by flat back (hypokyphosis) .

 This pattern is often seen in office workers and creates increased stress in the area between the
 shoulder blades.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Hallux Rigidus (Stiv Storta).

Behandling

 

 Behandlingen avhenger av graden av artrose. Ved grad 1-2 er konservativ behandling førstevalg.

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 
 Kiropraktisk behandling

 
 Leddmobilisering: Forsiktig mobilisering kan bedre bevegelsen og redusere smerter

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Behandling av stram muskulatur og bindevev rundt leddet

 Øvelsesveiledning: Spesifikke Øvelser for å opprettholde bevegelse og styrke

 Fottoyrad: Veiledning om riktig fottoy og eventuelle innleggssaler

 
 

 
 Fottoy og hjelpemidler

 
 Stive saler (rocker-sole): Reduserer belastning på leddet

 Romslig taboks: Hindrer trykk mot kulen

 Lave heler: Reduserer dorsalfleksjon i leddet

 Morton's extension: Stivner salen under stortaen

 
 

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 
 Bevegelighetsoving

 Oppretthold bevegelse i leddet så lenge det er smertefritt:

 
 Sett deg ned og grip rundt stortaen

 Boy forsiktig stortaen opp og ned innenfor smertefritt område

 Hold 5 sekunder i hver retning

 Gjenta 10 ganger, 2-3 ganger daglig

 
 

 
 Styrkeovelse for fotmluskulatur

 
 Legg et handkle på gulvet

 Grip handklet med tårne og trekk det mot deg

 Gjenta til tårne er slitne

 Gjor dette 1-2 ganger daglig

 
 

 Når vurderes kirurgi?

 Ved grad 3-4 der konservativ behandling ikke gir tilstrekkelig lindring, kan kirurgi våre aktuelt:

 
 Cheilektomi: Fjerning av beinpalser (ved grad 1-2)

 Artrodese: Avstivning av leddet (ved grad 3-4)

 Leddprotese: Kan våre aktuelt i utvalgte tilfeller

Describe diagnosis for Snapping Hip.

Diagnosis

 Clinical Examination is Key

 In most cases, the diagnosis is clinical - meaning the examination provides the answer without the need
 for imaging. The most reliable test is reproducing the snap during examination.

 When is Imaging Needed?

 When the snap cannot be reproduced

 When labral tear is suspected

 When there is no improvement after 2-3 months

 With red flags

 When surgery is being considered

 Imaging Modalities

 Dynamic ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for snapping hip outside the
 joint. MR arthrography is the gold standard when labral tear is suspected, with
 approximately 90% sensitivity.

Beskriv Hva er tennisalbue? for Tennisalbue (Lateral Epikondylitt).

Hva er tennisalbue?

 

 Tennisalbue, eller lateral epikondylitt, er en smertefull tilstand som påvirker senefestet på utsiden av albuen. Her fester musklene som strekker handleddet og fingrene - de samme musklene du bruker når du løfter, griper og vrir.

 Men her kommer det viktige: tennisalbue er ikke en betennelse. Moderne forskning har vist at tilstanden er en degenerasjon (slitasje) av senen, ikke en inflammatorisk prosess. Derfor har begrepet "tendinose" erstattet "tendinitt" i fagmiljøer (Coombes et al., 2015).

 Hvem rammes?

 Til tross for navnet er det ironisk nok bare 5-10% av tilfellene som skyldes tennis. De fleste tilfellene oppstar fra:

 
 Repetitivt arbeid med mus og tastatur (musearm)

 Handverkerarbeid (snekring, maling, VVS)

 Husarbeid og hagearbeid

 Annen idrett (styrketrening, golf, badminton)

 

 
 
 1-3%
 av befolkningen rammes
 

 
 35-54 Ør
 vanligste aldersgruppe
 

 
 90%
 dominante arm

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for GTPS - Pain on the Outside of the Hip.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 What is the difference between GTPS and trochanteric bursitis?

 GTPS is an umbrella term that includes gluteal tendinopathy, bursitis, and
 muscle dysfunction. Research shows that most of the pain is caused by tendon problems, not bursitis.
 Treatment is similar regardless.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 GTPS often takes 6-9 months to treat effectively. The LEAP study showed that 79%
 were better after 1 year with proper exercise treatment. Getting worse before better is not unusual.
 

 

 
 Should I avoid lying on the painful side?

 Yes, in the acute phase. Side-lying compresses the tendons against the
 trochanter. Use a pillow between your knees or lie on the healthy side. Gradual acclimatization as
 pain subsides.

 

 
 Does stretching help?

 Be careful with stretching. Many stretching exercises compress the tendons and
 can make things worse. Focus on strength training instead.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but you need to adjust your training. Avoid exercises that cause a lot of
 pain, especially in end-range positions. Activities like cycling and swimming are often well
 tolerated.

Snapping hip er når du hØrer eller kjenner et 'klikk' eller 'smell' i hoften ved bevegelse. Det finnes tre typer: intern (iliopsoas over hofteleddet), ekstern (ITB over trokanter) og intraartikulær (inne i leddet). Intern snapping fra iliopsoas er den vanligste formen hos dansere og idrettsutøvere.

Describe causes and risk factors for Costochondritis and Chest Pain.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Causes of costochondritis, ranked from most common to rarest
 Common Causes

 Overexertion and repetitive movements - heavy lifting, intense training, prolonged
 coughing (most common)

 Post-viral conditions - often after respiratory infection with prolonged coughing

 Poor posture - combined with stiffness in the thoracic spine, can also cause pain between the shoulder blades 

 Direct trauma - blow to the chest, falls (see also rib dislocation )

 Fibromyalgia - increases the risk of costochondritis (less common)

 Idiopathic - in many cases no clear cause is found

 The Connection Between Thoracic Spine and Costochondritis

 In clinical practice, I often see that patients with costochondritis have concurrent stiffness in the
 thoracic spine. Grindstaff et al. (Journal of Manual & Manipulative Therapy, 2010) suggest a biomechanical
 explanation: when the joints in the back (facet joints and costovertebral joints) become stiff, the joints
 in the front of the chest must compensate with increased movement . Over time, this can
 irritate the cartilage.

 Biomechanical Connection

 The thoracic spine and ribs form a biomechanical ring - movement in one place affects the entire
 structure. This insight is important for treatment: by restoring normal mobility in the thoracic spine,
 you can often reduce the load on the cartilage connections in front.

Assess red flags: 50-year-old male with bilateral leg heaviness after 10 km run. Bilateral foot numbness that resolved after 20 minutes. Normal urination. No back pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why this is NOT cauda equina:
- Bilateral leg heaviness after prolonged running is normal (muscular fatigue)
- Transient foot numbness = compression neuropathy from shoes/loading, NOT saddle anesthesia
- Saddle anesthesia means numbness in the PERINEUM (groin/anus), not feet
- Normal bladder function rules out sphincter involvement
- No back pain (CES almost always presents with back pain)

Clinical picture: Exertion-related transient peripheral neuropathy.

Safe to treat. Recommend footwear change and gradual training progression.

Describe What is carpal tunnel syndrome? for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

What is carpal tunnel syndrome?

 

 Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) occurs when the median nerve is compressed in the carpal
 tunnel - a narrow passage on the inside of the wrist. This tunnel is surrounded by the wrist bones on
 three sides and a tight band (the carpal ligament) on top.

 When pressure in the tunnel increases, the nerve is compressed. This causes the characteristic symptoms:
 tingling, numbness and pain in the fingers supplied by the nerve - the thumb, index finger, middle finger
 and half of the ring finger.

 
 The little finger is the key

 If the little finger is also affected, it is not carpal tunnel syndrome - it's
 supplied by the ulnar nerve (see cubital tunnel syndrome).
 This is an important diagnostic sign.

 

 
 
 2.7%
 of population affected
 

 
 3x
 more common in women
 

 
 40-60 years
 most common age group

Patient asks: "What's the difference between cubital and carpal tunnel syndrome?"

Cubital tunnel syndrome affects the ulnar nerve at the ELBOW and causes symptoms in the little finger and ring finger. Carpal tunnel syndrome affects the median nerve at the WRIST and causes symptoms in the thumb, index, middle and ring fingers.
